As of March 13th, over 145,000 cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed in more than 130 countries and territories. Major outbreaks were in mainland China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran.

As of March 13th, there were over 145,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in approximately 140 countries and territories. The most significant outbreaks are in mainland China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran.
Between 29 and 52 Muslims were killed and more than 100 others were wounded during riots in Hebron.
29 Muslims were killed and over 100 wounded during riots in Hebron.
By March 26th, over 21,300 deaths were linked to COVID-19.
By March 27th, over 26,300 fatalities were linked to COVID-19.
By March 28th, Spain had 5,138 deaths, 4,165 people hospitalized in intensive care, and conducted more than 350,000 COVID-19 tests.

By March 28th, Spain had conducted more than 350,000 COVID-19 tests, resulting in at least 5,812 deaths and 4,165 hospitalizations in intensive care units. Of those in intensive care, 1,312 were in the Community of Madrid.
By February 29th, Italy had conducted over 18,500 tests for the virus.
As of March 1st, Italy had conducted 21,127 tests for the virus.

Qatar Airways is headquartered in Doha and operates out of Hamad International Airport. The airline flies to over 160 destinations across the globe, utilizing a hub-and-spoke network and a fleet of over 200 aircraft.

Qatar Airways, headquartered in Doha, Qatar, operates out of Hamad International Airport. The airline flies to over 150 destinations across Africa, Central Asia, Europe, Far East, South Asia, Middle East, North America, South America and Oceania, utilizing a hub-and-spoke network and a fleet of over 200 aircraft.
Maxthon, the second most popular browser in China, has over 400 million downloads globally.
Maxthon, the second most popular browser in China, has over 500 million downloads globally.
Globally, there have been over 16,700 confirmed fatalities and more than 102,000 recoveries from the disease.
Globally, there are over 392,000 reported cases, exceeding 17,100 deaths and 102,000 recoveries.

Paul Merson, known for his criticism of Andros Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, reignited the feud after Townsend's brief appearance in Tottenham's draw with Burnley. Merson's initial criticism stemmed from Townsend's early substitution during a match against Manchester United, leading him to believe Townsend didn't deserve a spot on the England team. However, Townsend proved Merson wrong by scoring a stunning equalizer for England against Italy, a feat Merson acknowledged and admitted he was wrong about. Despite seemingly burying the hatchet, Merson reignited the feud after Townsend's late-game substitution for Tottenham.

Chelsea have made an offer to FC Tokyo for their 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto.  Muto would be loaned to Vitesse Arnhem, Chelsea's Dutch partner club, if he completes the move.  Muto would be the first Japanese player to play for Chelsea.  He graduated from Keio University with an economics degree and was named to the J-League's best XI after scoring 13 goals in his first season.  While a £4 million deal has been discussed, Muto has not yet decided if he will join the Premier League team.

A study published in *Pediatrics* found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese by the age of two. Researchers compared the weight and height data of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with antibiotic prescription records and found that children given antibiotics as babies were more likely to be overweight, with boys being particularly susceptible to weight gain. While the study didn't definitively prove causation, researchers suggest that antibiotics may kill gut bacteria that normally consume food, leading to increased caloric absorption and potentially increased appetite. This study highlights concerns about the over-prescription of antibiotics and their potential link to the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

A Queen's Guard soldier slipped and fell during the Changing of the Guard ceremony at Buckingham Palace. The incident, captured on video by tourist David Meadwell, shows the guard slipping on a manhole cover, falling, and dropping his rifle. Despite the attention from the crowd, the guard quickly recovered and rejoined the ceremony. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E Networks will air a remake of the 1977 miniseries "Roots" in 2016. The original miniseries, which depicted the story of Kunta Kinte, an African sold into slavery in America, drew over 100 million viewers. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the 1977 miniseries, will co-executive produce the remake. Producers intend for the updated series to be a more authentic adaptation of Haley’s novel.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler (64), has alleged that he was the victim of an attempted orgy by palace aides at Clarence House in 1978.  Lawler claims he was groped and restrained, but managed to escape. He reported the incident that day, but left the job immediately after a purported angry response from Clarence House.  Lawler contacted the Palace again in 2022 after news of investigations into historical child sex abuse. After being rebuffed twice, his complaint was forwarded to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide has been interviewed, but denies involvement. The Palace has stated they will cooperate fully with the police investigation.

Jesse and Melissa Meek, an Oregon couple, announced their pregnancy in a rap video parody of the "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" theme song. The video, filmed after only two months of trying to conceive, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood and ends with a sonogram reveal. The video, intended for family and friends, unexpectedly went viral, garnering over 1.7 million views on YouTube.  The Meeks, who found out about the pregnancy after Melissa placed a tag on their dog, are considering making another video to reveal the gender of their child.

A slate blue-gray dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold at auction for $137,000. The dress, now faded to light gray, was part of a collection of memorabilia from the film amassed by James Tumblin, formerly in charge of the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. Other items from the film sold at auction include a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, trousers and a jacket from a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia de Havilland as Melanie Wilkes for $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday after his parents dangled him over the edge. He fell 10-12 feet and was rescued by his parents. The boy was unharmed by the cheetahs. He was taken to the hospital in stable condition and suffered minor injuries. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the parents.

A non-functioning speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham that had been enforcing the 30mph speed limit has been turned to face a house. Around 300 speed and traffic cameras in the West Midlands using old technology were turned off in 2013 and replaced with mobile camera units, fixed cameras on motorways, and traffic officers.  An engineer will be sent to the site of the camera and it may be removed completely. While there are plans to test new digital camera technology at a limited number of sites, the Wellington Road camera will not be included.

Usain Bolt will be part of the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2nd and 3rd. Bolt stated he is “fit, healthy and ready to run” and that he is happy to be part of the Jamaican team.  The JAAA General Secretary expressed excitement about Bolt’s participation and expects “sprint magic” from him on the track.

Neymar and teammate Dani Alves recently attended a Euro League basketball game between Barcelona and Real Madrid to support their club's basketball team.  Although Real Madrid won the game, Barcelona's basketball team remains just behind them in the Euro League.  Neymar is coming off a win with the Brazilian national team where they defeated Chile. He will rejoin his Barcelona teammates when they play Celta Vigo as they continue their quest to win a treble of trophies.

Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued in the Mediterranean Sea, according to the Italian coast guard. Save the Children fears that 400 migrants are missing after receiving reports of a capsized ship carrying 550 people. However, the Italian coast guard cannot confirm the incident.  The International Organization for Migration (IOM) stated Italy received over 10,000 migrants in the first three months of 2015, with an additional 2,000 rescued by sea in early April. Most of the migrants originated from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, with Libya serving as a transit country. The IOM has recorded at least 480 migrant deaths this year due to factors such as inclement weather, overcrowded vessels, and smugglers abandoning ships.

Alexis Sanchez had his choice of clubs after leaving Barcelona. Liverpool was interested in Sanchez, especially as a potential replacement for Luis Suarez, who transferred to Barcelona. Ultimately, Sanchez chose to sign with Arsenal and has had a strong season, scoring 19 goals.  Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased Sanchez chose Arsenal and believes Sanchez's talent has been key to the team's success.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's prestigious hour record at the Lee Valley VeloPark on June 7.  Wiggins will be chasing the current record of 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Tickets for the event go on sale April 19th.

Despite winning her match against Sara Errani, Serena Williams admitted that the near loss was an “eye-opener” that showed her lack of preparedness for the clay court season.  Williams, along with teammate Alison Riske, lost their doubles match against Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the US team’s relegation to World Group II.  The US team captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, is hopeful that the team can regain their place among the elite nations with continued hard work.

Radamel Falcao, a former River Plate striker who played for the team for 8 years before a successful career in Europe, may return to his former club.  The Colombian striker has struggled this season while on loan at Manchester United, but River Plate's vice president says "the doors are open" for a return to the club where he scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a finalist on the television program "The X Factor" and pop star, is the new face of the dry shampoo brand, Batiste.  The international "Ready For It" campaign features Henderson modeling a variety of hairstyles, showcasing the use of Batiste products. This is Henderson's first brand collaboration.

Aaron Siler, a man wanted for felony probation and parole violation, was shot and killed by Kenosha police officer Pablo Torres on March 14th.  The incident occurred after a vehicle and foot pursuit, during which Siler brandished a weapon.  This was Torres' second shooting of the month, having shot 66 year old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives, on March 4th.  While the investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, District Attorney Robert Zapf determined that the shooting of Knight was justified.  A billboard erected in Kenosha featuring Torres and his dog with the caption "Thank you for your support, Kenosha" has sparked outrage among Siler's family and friends.  Paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, the billboard was intended to thank the community for their support following the recent incidents.  Siler's family and friends, however, found the billboard disrespectful and are calling for its removal.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed by the militant group Jaish al Adal near the border of Pakistan. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian group, claimed responsibility for the attack, stating their aim is to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan.  Iranian officials state the militants crossed the border from Pakistan and have asked Pakistani authorities to apprehend the surviving assailants. Pakistan condemned the attack and is investigating the incident.

Responding to a question from lawmaker and former wrestler Antonio Inoki, Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told parliament that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects, although it scrambles jets to investigate unidentified flying objects that could violate Japan's airspace.  They have, however, never found an unidentified flying object that came from somewhere other than Earth.

A 35 year old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized after he broke a toilet and sustained injuries to his leg and buttocks.  The incident occurred at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport.  He was standing on the rim of the toilet to avoid contact because he was concerned it was not clean.  The toilet broke, causing him to fall and sustain injuries.  Although he initially told his friends he was squatting on the toilet, he later told police he was sitting on the toilet when it broke.  Police believe the incident was an accident and reminded people that toilets are for sitting on.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, was arrested in Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, on charges of aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. A 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera placed by Rebbie in her bathroom, revealing footage of her and others, including juveniles, undressed. Rebbie admitted to filming the victims, specifically targeting the 15-year-old for years. He faces a preliminary hearing on May 1 and is held on a $500,000 bail.

Yuki Aoyama, a 37-year-old Japanese photographer, has created a photo series depicting daughters standing next to their jumping fathers.  The photos are part of a book project entitled "Daughter and Salaryman," with each photo showing the daughter solemnly facing the camera while their fathers leap in a serious suit.  The photos, taken in front of various Japanese landmarks, have garnered online attention for their unique concept.

Kevin Pietersen participated in Surrey's team photo shoot ahead of the start of the County Championship season.  Pietersen was in a jovial mood as he joked with teammates and photographers.  Pietersen rejoined Surrey in hopes of making his way back onto the England Test team after being controversially cut in 2014 by the former managing director, Paul Downton.  Surrey begins their season against Glamorgan on April 19.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt fired coach Ze Maria after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani that left the team in 16th place, six points away from safety.  This is the second time Ze Maria has been fired in a week, only to be reinstated by owner Angelo Massone after the first dismissal.  He had been Ceahlaul's third coach this season. Serbian Vanya Radinovic will replace him.

Radamel Falcao's loan to Manchester United has not gone well. He has not performed as well as he had before a serious knee injury he sustained prior to the loan.  His former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar states that Falcao was unhappy in Monaco but believes he should have stayed there, as he would have played in the Champions League.

On Saturday in Christchurch, a man wearing a bright orange sweatshirt and a cartoon mask robbed a dairy on Union St.  The man, described as “very tall”, stole the cash register containing approximately $1500.  The dairy owner’s daughter, who was present during the robbery, described the man as “scary”. Police are asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested on March 19th for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student where she admitted kissing the student and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail but arrested again on Monday following a second 15-year-old student alleging Granado had sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. Granado is currently on administrative leave and unable to work with students or be present on any Irving ISD property.

A crocodile was filmed swimming in a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico with a dead dog in its mouth.  The dog belonged to the owner of a local bike shop and approached the water, where it was snatched by the crocodile.  The crocodile swam in the marina with the dog in its mouth for hours.  Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta, as the resort is built near mangroves where the animals live.  "American Crocodiles" in Mexico can grow to 6 meters long and live close to humans in the area.

Despite losing 2-0 to Southampton, Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident that the team will avoid relegation from the Premier League.  He believes that the team can secure the two wins needed to stay afloat. Hull City is currently two points above the relegation zone. Bruce attributes Hull City’s struggles to key players being sidelined due to injury. Southampton manager Ronald Koeman will address his team about Sadio Mane attempting to take a penalty kick from designated penalty taker James Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, instructed students to alter answers on their SATs exams after the exam session had ended. Guffick also changed a number of student's answers himself. Following an investigation, the Department for Education annulled the SATs results for the entire school. Guffick, who claimed he asked students to make their answers more legible, admitted to the allegations and accepted his behavior was unacceptable. The National College for Teaching and Leadership banned Guffick from the classroom for a minimum of two years, acknowledging his remorse but emphasizing the severity of his actions and their impact on the school.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri. The couple, who wed in 2014, have a son together and reside in Cheshire. Although Lindegaard has not had much success on the field, playing in only 19 league appearances in 5 seasons, he is clearly very happy in his personal life.

Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson's 10-foot-tall, glowing blue "Yankee Stadium" letters, which hung above the stadium from 1976 to 2008, failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction. Despite an estimated worth of $300,000 to $600,000, the only bid was $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee.  However, a Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers spoke with Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their off-field conduct, reminding them of their responsibilities as professional athletes. While photos surfaced of Sterling and Ibe using legal substances, Rodgers will not discipline either player and wants to move forward. Rodgers is focused on leading Liverpool to the FA Cup final, especially after last season's losses in the title race and Capital One Cup.  Rodgers believes that setbacks are part of the journey and will use those experiences to improve.

Mesut Ozil, who recently returned to London following an international break where he played well in Germany's 2-0 defeat of Georgia, was reported to have been seen in a Berlin nightclub.  Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger refuted those claims. Ozil missed the Arsenal game, a 2-1 defeat of Newcastle, due to illness, but is expected to start against Liverpool at Emirates Stadium. Since his return from injury in January, he has scored three goals and has four assists.  Ozil believes he is finally adjusting to English football.

Josep Maria Bartomeu, the president of the Barcelona club, has stated that the club has no plans to replace their manager, Luis Enrique. Bartomeu says the club is  'very happy' with Enrique, who took charge of the club last summer on a two-year deal. Enrique's contract is through 2016.  Bartomeu commented on Enrique's dedication to the team, specifically citing the manager's work ethic in preparing for the Valencia game following a Champions League game against PSG.  Barcelona defeated Valencia with a final score of 2-0. Goals were scored by Luis Suarez in the first minute of the game and Lionel Messi later in the match.

Jordan Henderson, the vice-captain of Liverpool, has agreed to a contract extension with the club.  The new deal will see him through 2020, earning him around £100,000 a week.  Henderson, whose previous contract was set to expire in 14 months, has been a standout performer for Liverpool and is slated to be considered for the captain's role when Steven Gerrard departs.

Filipe Luis, despite rumors of Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him, has stated his desire to remain at Chelsea for the duration of his three-year contract.  Although he has not yet secured a starting position, Luis maintains that he is happy at Chelsea.  Meanwhile, as the Premier League title race heats up, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho urges his players, including Luis, to remain focused and committed to winning each remaining game.

Nathan Hughes' three-match ban, for accidentally striking George North's head with his knee, was overturned on appeal.  Although Hughes received a red card during the match, the appeals panel determined that no foul play occurred, citing the incident was accidental.  As a result of the appeal, Hughes is eligible to play immediately.

Seattle resident Tim Durkan recently captured stunning sunset pictures featuring an unusual reddish color over the city. The source of this phenomenon was traced back to wildfires in southeastern Siberia. Although the fires have been extinguished, smoke particles traveled across the Pacific Ocean, impacting the Pacific Northwest's atmosphere. The abundance of smoke particles filters out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing reds and oranges to dominate, especially during sunrise and sunset. As the smoke dissipates, air quality is expected to improve, and sunsets will return to their normal hues.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway. The car was found after a man who recognized it contacted the police. The car was returned with red spray paint on the rims and sides, orange accents on the steering wheel, and a strong odor of cigarettes and marijuana. Schoenig is getting the car professionally cleaned and, in honor of the man who found her car, she is creating a smoothie called the Sexton on Wheels.

Manchester City players will lose out on £500,000 bonuses, equaling a total of £12 million, if they fail to finish in the top four and qualify for the Champions League.  A fourth-place finish would require the team to win a qualifying round to join the top three teams who automatically qualify.  Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team has played poorly in the last three months of the season, impacting their standing.

Manchester United defeated Manchester City 1-0 in an under 18s game. Callum Gribbin scored the only goal on a direct free kick.  Many of the players were from Manchester, England.  The game was played at Altrincham's stadium which has a 6,000 person capacity.  Manchester United manager Paul McGuinness wanted his team to get experience in a more professional setting.

Joe Hart, who recently earned his 50th cap playing for England, called Gianluigi Buffon, who earned his 147th cap in the same match, a "legend of the game" and "inspirational." The 37-year-old Buffon, who plays for Italy and Juventus, is ten years older than Hart.  Hart, who plays for England and Manchester City, stated that he hopes to continue to represent his country.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to offer delivery service in 67 cities.  A nine percent service charge will be applied to orders, in addition to Postmates delivery fees.  Chipotle joins Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King in capitalizing on the lucrative food delivery market.

The parents of Martin Richard, an 8-year-old who was killed in the Boston Marathon bombing, are publicly asking the Justice Department to no longer seek the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving bomber.  They argue that while they understand the nature of the crimes, continuing to seek the death penalty will prolong their pain with years of appeals and prevent their family, and the city of Boston, from healing.

A mystery billionaire has spent an estimated £400 million to have a Boeing 747 customized into a luxury private jet. The plane, which can normally hold 600 passengers, features amenities such as a dining room, kitchen, lounge, bedrooms, guest rooms, and an office.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station. Although the rocket successfully landed on a drone ship, it tipped over and did not survive. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the ISS and return to Earth with 3,000 pounds of cargo. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel located in the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas. The wedding will take place on April 23, 2015, and is part of a contest held by NBC's Today Show. The winning couple will receive a wedding, reception, two-night hotel stay, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla Presley was involved in the design of the chapel, which is the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside of the late singer's Memphis home.

Liverpool defeated Newcastle 2-0 on Monday night.  The win, secured by goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, keeps Liverpool's Premier League title hopes alive. Despite trailing Manchester City by four points, Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes that his team can still catch them.

Roma defeated Napoli 1-0 on Saturday to end a four-month winless streak at home. Miralem Pjanic scored the lone goal in the 25th minute off an assist from Alessandro Florenzi.  Roma goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis deflected several scoring attempts by Napoli in the second half to secure the victory.  Roma moved to second place, four points ahead of Lazio. Napoli remained in fifth place, extending their winless streak to five matches.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played a lackluster match that ended in a 0-0 draw.  The match was so uneventful that the 27-second highlight video on the club's YouTube channel only featured 14 seconds of action, including the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has a unique bond with his pet blood parrot cichlid, which he documents on his YouTube channel.  The fish enjoys being stroked and massaged by Giroux, even swimming back to his hand for more.  Giroux developed this relationship with the fish after noticing it was being bullied by its tankmates, which he removed.  He began interacting with the fish more, hand-feeding it and eventually stroking it. Now, the fish expects daily interaction with Giroux and becomes upset if he doesn't.

Ben Stokes is known for his fiery personality and aggressive style of play, which has sometimes led to on-field conflicts. While England's management team recognizes the need to guide Stokes in managing his aggression, they also appreciate the passion and excitement he brings to the game. The team aims to support Stokes' development and provide him with opportunities to excel in international cricket, believing that his potential outweighs the risks associated with his temperament.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12th at Cardiff City Stadium has sold out its 33,000 seats.  The high demand for tickets follows Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel, which propelled them to the top of Group B based on goal difference.  Although the larger Millennium Stadium was considered as a venue option, UEFA rules prohibit venue changes within 120 days of the match. Furthermore, the Welsh team prefers playing at Cardiff City Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The Young Lions are the defending champions and won all of their qualifying matches.  The squad contains talented young players from a host of Premier League clubs including Chelsea and Arsenal. Their group stage matches are as follows: May 7th against Italy, May 10th against Holland, and May 13th against Ireland.

Manchester City are interested in signing Evangelos Patoulidis, a 14 year-old playmaker from Anderlecht, who is considered one of the top youth prospects.  Patoulidis has garnered interest from Arsenal and Barcelona, the latter of which he rejected at age 12 to continue his studies. To secure Patoulidis, Manchester City have spoken with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock  in hopes of reaching a compensation agreement.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort originally from Mexico, was found dead in a Fulham flat at the end of March.  She died from head and neck injuries resulting from strangulation and beating.  A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has since been released on bail.  Police are asking anyone who may have had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward as they continue their investigation.

Dawn, a woman who endured seven miscarriages, appeared on the Jeremy Kyle show accusing her housemate Jamie of stealing £207 she had saved for a gravestone for one of her babies.  Jamie initially denied the theft, but a lie detector test revealed he had taken the money.  Jamie later confessed to Dawn in a Facebook message, blaming his girlfriend for the theft.  Dawn was devastated by the betrayal, expressing her desire to use the money to give her baby Daniel James a proper memorial.

ISIS released 217-228 Yazidis, mostly women and children, some elderly and ill, according to Iraqi and Kurdish officials.  It is unclear why they were released, but Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate it. ISIS overtook Yazidi towns in Northern Iraq last summer, killing, capturing, and displacing members of the minority group.  After the August conquest of Sinjar, many fled to the mountains or to Syria, and hundreds were slaughtered.  Some female captives were reportedly raped and enslaved.  The U.S. estimates 500,000 Yazidis live in Northern Iraq.

Harry Kane, who has had a breakout season with Tottenham and earned a spot on England's national team, is nominated for two PFA awards. A new animation by Copa90 highlights some of Kane's top goals and celebrations from this season. The video, titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?", was released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane is competing against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Despite Liverpool’s failure to win a trophy for the third consecutive year and their likely absence from the Champions League next season, Jamie Carragher has voiced his support for Brendan Rodgers to remain as the club’s manager. Carragher believes that Rodgers' job is to identify areas for improvement and make the necessary signings to strengthen the squad. He also highlighted the importance of making the right signings to ensure progress for the following season.

Four-year-old James Hayward's toy gun was confiscated at East Midlands Airport because it was deemed a security risk. Despite the parents' protest, airport security took the toy gun, stating that "no items may be permitted through security that resemble a prohibited item." Although the airport offered to return the toy gun, the family purchased a new one upon returning from their trip.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. Describing himself as athletic, wealthy, and successful, he outlined a list of requirements for the "successful candidate," including being fit, attractive, honest, and good in bed. He offered perks like a gym membership, phone, and potential use of a company car, laptop, and accommodation.

FA Chairman Greg Dyke, backed by five former England managers, proposes to increase the minimum number of homegrown players in club squads from eight to twelve, with “homegrown” being redefined as trained in England for three years before the age of 18. They argue that this is necessary to improve the English national team, as the pool of English talent in the Premier League is shrinking, with only 36.8% of starters in recent matches being English-qualified. They believe that while England can produce top young talent, these players need more opportunities to play at the highest level.

In the upcoming episode of the show Poldark, Demelza, played by actress Eleanor Tomlinson, will give birth to her and Ross Poldark’s (played by Aidan Turner) daughter, only a short time after announcing her pregnancy in the previous episode. Fans have pointed out the unrealistic timeline of the pregnancy, comparing it to a similarly fast pregnancy that occurred in a previous episode with another character, Elizabeth.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson, despite his team's back-to-back wins and improved chances of avoiding relegation, has cautioned his players against becoming overconfident. He stressed the importance of focusing solely on their own performance in upcoming matches, rather than becoming distracted by the performance of their rivals. Pearson believes that by maintaining this focus, Leicester can give themselves a fighting chance of staying in the Premier League.

A gray whale named Varvara broke the record for the longest mammal migration, swimming 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey, surpassing the previous 10,190-mile record held by a humpback whale, suggests that Varvara may be an eastern gray whale, not a western gray whale as previously thought. This has implications for the estimated 150 western gray whales believed to exist, as it indicates potential misclassification and a need for further genetic study.

A new stretch of coastline emerged on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, near the town of Rausu. Measuring roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, the land rose 30 to 50ft above sea level after a landslide. Geologists believe melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop, which forced a section of the seabed to the surface. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds, indicating the landmass appeared suddenly. Authorities confirmed the event is unrelated to earthquakes and do not believe it will expand further.

Gregory van der Wiel, despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc that led to his benching, has stated his desire to stay with Paris Saint-Germain. He expressed his love for the club, city, and teammates, and aims to sign a contract extension. However, PSG's interest in Dani Alves may impact Van der Wiel's future with the team.

Carlos Tevez, who is under contract with Juventus until the end of next season, has expressed his desire to return to his former club, Boca Juniors. Boca Juniors have confirmed they are close to finalizing a deal but Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Juventus is reluctant to lose Tevez, as he is currently the league's top scorer, but they have accepted his decision and are pursuing replacements.  Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, has stated that a move to Boca Juniors would not negatively impact Tevez's spot on the Argentinian national team.

During Bayern Munich's 6-1 win over Porto, manager Pep Guardiola ripped his trousers, revealing his underwear.  The incident happened in the midst of Bayern's dominating performance, which included a 5-0 lead by halftime.  The win secured Bayern Munich a place in the Champions League semi-finals.

A three-car collision on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, resulted in ten individuals, including four children, being hospitalized. Two adults and two children were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane, while six others, including an infant and two young girls, were transported to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped inside their vehicle and had to be freed by emergency crews using hydraulic cutting gear. The highway was temporarily closed with diversions in place.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil showed off his new Apple Watch on social media. Ozil is expected to start against Chelsea on Sunday. Meanwhile, Arsenal legend Ray Parlour believes that Jack Wilshere’s fitness record is the one thing holding him back from reaching his potential.  Wilshere recently returned to the bench after five months out due to injury.

Mark Clattenburg will be the referee for the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City.  This is notable because he has previously given red cards to players from both teams.  Manchester City captain Vincent Kompany was sent off during the recent international break, while Manchester United players Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw were dismissed earlier in the season.

Bob Katter, a federal MP, released a statement accusing the Queensland government of assuming that MP Billy Gordon would quit after allegations of domestic violence and a concealed criminal past surfaced. Katter believes that the government assumed Gordon would quit due to racist attitudes and that they viewed him as a "black puppet" they could control. Katter's statement has drawn criticism on social media for his use of the term "black puppet." Katter defended his statement, citing his own experiences with racism and stating that he used the term because he himself is "dark" and understands the racist attitudes directed at Gordon.

Dayna Dobias, a 19 year old with cerebral palsy, combats negativity and stereotypes surrounding disabilities by creating motivational dance videos.  She wants to inspire others to see past her disability and treat her like anyone else.  Dayna wants to change how people with disabilities are portrayed in media and entertainment.  She is an advocate who also speaks at schools, encouraging others to see past their disability.

Orlando City is interested in acquiring Javier Hernandez from Manchester United. Hernandez has had a difficult season on loan to Real Madrid, but many teams are still interested in the forward. Orlando City thinks the Mexican striker would be a huge draw for their large Latin-American fanbase.  Manchester United has offered Andreas Pereira, a 19-year-old midfielder, a revised contract after his rejection of their initial offer.  Pereira played in a game against Aston Villa after numerous European clubs contacted Pereira's representation about the midfielder's potential signing.

Early Saturday morning around 12:15 am, a man driving a white Dodge Charger was in an argument with a group of at least three people at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles. The suspects attempted to carjack the man, and when he ran away, they doused his car in gasoline and set it on fire with two passengers still inside. No one was injured, but the car was ruined. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large.

Charles Manuel, an Iowa chiropractor, surrendered his medical license after admitting to unethical practices. These practices included accepting sex as payment and performing exorcisms.  Manuel is barred from seeking reinstatement for at least 10 years.  Despite these transgressions, patient satisfaction surveys on Healthgrade.com were positive.

The U.S. will issue a complaint to Russia through diplomatic channels after a Russian fighter jet intercepted a U.S. reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea. The Pentagon alleges the Russian SU-27 Flanker made aggressive maneuvers in close proximity to the American RC-135U, endangering the U.S. crew. Russia state news claims the U.S. plane had its transponder switched off while flying toward the Russian border, an allegation denied by a U.S. European Command official. This is not the first incident of its kind, as a similar event occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of a Salt Lake City Marriott Springhill Suites hotel, where he was staying, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was in a locked case and secured to the car; however, police believe the thief broke the passenger window, tied a rope to the case, and used the momentum of a vehicle to detach the case. The rifle has not been recovered, but its serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012. Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa's mental state was compromised by dementia and alcohol abuse during the time of the murder.  Professor Mullen cited Costa's fluctuating mood during the 911 calls and the trail of feces from the crime scene to the toilet where Costa was found as evidence of his compromised mental state. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa feigned his failing memory during examinations, a claim that Professor Mullen denies. Costa's mental state is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not-guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack is proven.

Everton beat Burnley 1-0 after Ross Barkley took a penalty instead of Leighton Baines, who is usually the team's penalty taker. Manager Roberto Martinez defended the decision, stating that Barkley had the right to choose to take the penalty and that Baines supported the decision.  Though Barkley's penalty was saved, Everton won after a goal from Mirallas.
Two passengers were found dead on Holland America Line's ms Ryndam cruise ship on Thursday at 11:30 a.m.  The deaths appear to be a murder-suicide. The FBI is investigating the deaths.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led the Caribbean island team of Curacao to the second round of World Cup qualifying matches. Curacao defeated Montserrat 4-3 in a two-leg match, with the last goal scored in the 87th minute by former Holland Under 21 international Charlton Vicento. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8th and 16th.

Esteban Cambiasso, who has won all the major European competitions a player can during his career, says that helping keep Leicester in the Premier League will feel like winning a trophy. Leicester City is currently in last place in the Premier League and seven points adrift with only eight games left to play. Cambiasso believes that Leicester City can avoid relegation and is happy with his time at Leicester and may stay beyond his one-year contract.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two, has relinquished the care of her children to her own mother, Debbie. Debbie criticizes Gemma's lifestyle choices, stating that her daughter prioritizes drinking and partying over her children. This has led Debbie to the point where she is considering banning Gemma from seeing the children due to her untrustworthiness and neglectful behavior.

John Terry made a strong challenge on Radamel Falcao during the scoring sequence that led to Eden Hazard's opening goal for Chelsea against Manchester United.  Although it was a goal, pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agree that play should have been stopped for the foul on Falcao by Terry.

While traveling on Interstate 30, near Dallas, a tour bus carrying Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott caught fire after a tire blowout.  Scott, along with her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated before the fire engulfed the back of the bus, destroying everything except a Bible. The band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is still scheduled to perform at the Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, from Dundee University, proposes using space lasers to convert sunlight into energy that can be beamed to Earth. Satellites equipped with mirrors would orbit Earth, capturing sunlight and converting it into laser light. This energy would then be transmitted to Earth, potentially powering homes and aiding disaster-stricken areas. While the lasers wouldn't be potent enough for weaponry, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges concerns about potential misuse of the technology.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted pedophile, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit where he was detained under the Mental Health Act. He was last seen leaving the hospital near Hook, Hampshire, on Tuesday at 6:15 pm. Munden is described as 5ft 8 inches tall, of heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard. He was sentenced last August for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus and possessing indecent images of children. Police urge anyone with information to come forward as a matter of urgency.

V. Stiviano has been ordered by a Los Angeles judge to return more than $2.6 million in gifts to the Sterling family. The order comes after Rochelle Sterling, Donald Sterling's wife at the time, sued Stiviano for targeting her husband and using marital funds to purchase Stiviano a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Donald Sterling was banned from the NBA in 2014 after an audio recording surfaced of him making racist remarks to Stiviano.

Thierry Henry believes Arsenal need to buy four top-quality players in order to challenge for the Premier League title: a goalkeeper, a center back, a defensive midfielder, and a striker. He feels that while Olivier Giroud has performed well, he is not the caliber of striker that can lead a team to a championship. Henry points to Chelsea's success after signing Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa last season as an example of the impact such signings can have.

Maurice Van Ryn, the Bega Cheese boss, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. One of his victims told the court about the severe impact the abuse has had on her life, stating that she was unaware it was wrong at the time and that it has affected her mental health and relationships. Van Ryn did not make eye contact with the victim as she read her statement.

Serge Gnabry, a 19 year old midfielder for Arsenal, is nearing his return after a serious knee injury in March 2014.  After playing 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading, Gnabry feels his injury is behind him and is looking forward to rejoining the main squad.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died from an accidental fall after running from a taxi to avoid paying a fare. After a night out drinking with friends, Mr. Phillips and his friends ran from the taxi while en route to a friend's house. Running into the darkness, Mr. Phillips fell 70ft down a cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. The coroner ruled his death accidental, stating that Mr. Phillips was likely disoriented and unaware of the danger he faced.

Although the UK Passport Office had a backlog of more than half a million passports in 2014, causing many travelers to miss their trips or pay extra fees to expedite their passports, only 2,191 out of thousands of compensation applications were approved. The total payout was £203,066, with an average sum of £92.68.  The HM Passport Office made a surplus of £42.3 million between April and October of that year and paid out  £1.8 million in bonuses to managers.

A three-bedroom house in Horfield, Bristol, preserved since the 1930s, is going to auction on April 30th. The house features original details, including stained-glass windows, a mint green and black bathroom suite, and a kitchen with original cupboards. While some features have been modernized, such as the addition of double glazing, the guide price of £200,000-£250,000 reflects the potential renovation costs. Auctioneers believe the property would be ideal for antique enthusiasts.

Colin Kaepernick started his career as a backup quarterback for the 49ers. When the starting quarterback, Alex Smith, was injured, Kaepernick became the starter and led the team to the Super Bowl, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food, a comedy-drama film, was released in 1997. The film was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel. Fox 2000 Pictures released the film.

This passage provides brief biographical information about Anne Rice, stating she was born in New Orleans and lived there early in life before moving to Texas and later San Francisco. It then shifts focus to describe Route 495, a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey. This freeway connects the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) to New York State Route 495 within the Lincoln Tunnel, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.

Telemundo, pronounced [ teleˈmundo ], is an American television network that broadcasts in Spanish. The network is owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises, a division of NBCUniversal.
Damon Albarn, raised in England, formed the band Blur with Graham Coxon. Blur released their debut album *Leisure* in 1991.  Albarn's debut solo album *Everyday Robots* was released in 2014.
Mogadishu, also called Muqdisho or مقديشو locally, is the capital and largest city in Somalia.  As the capital, Mogadishu is home to many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails, featured on their first EP, *Broken*, which was released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The film *Shooter* (2007) features Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran, who is framed for murder. The TV series *Shooter* stars Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman, who comes out of exile to foil an assassination attempt on the president.
"House", also known as "House, M.D.", is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate. The murders were carried out by members of Manson's group, following his instructions.  Manson also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After he was charged, recordings of Manson's music were commercially released.

Sean Penn is an American actor who debuted in 1981 following a brief television appearance in 1974.  After a variety of roles, his performances in "At Close Range", "State of Grace", and "Carlito's Way" brought him critical acclaim.  He became a leading actor, receiving an Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival for "Dead Man Walking" (1995).  He received two more Oscar nominations before winning Best Actor awards for "Mystic River" (2003) and "Milk" (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, widely known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer considered the greatest batsman of all time.  Following his retirement, he remained a prominent figure in the sport, serving as an administrator, selector, and writer for thirty years.
L.A. Reid has held executive positions, including chairman and CEO, at three major record labels: Epic Records, Arista Records, and the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer, most famous for his time with rock bands Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. He co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha.  He was also a member of the band Prophets of Rage.

"The Millers", a multi-camera sitcom, aired on CBS for two seasons, from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015, totalling 34 episodes. Despite airing for two seasons, CBS cancelled the show on November 14, 2014, during the airing of its second season.

Ann Richards (1933-2006) was the 45th governor of Texas and a Democrat.  She was the second woman to hold the office of Texas governor, serving from 1991 to 1995.  Richards was defeated by George W. Bush in her re-election bid.  She was first recognized nationally while serving as Texas state treasurer after delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention.
Drake Bell independently released his EP, *A Reminder*, in 2011.
Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona.

Simón Bolívar (1783-1830), also known as "El Libertador," was a Venezuelan military and political leader who was instrumental in gaining independence from Spain for Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama.
The Bermuda Triangle, located in the western North Atlantic Ocean, is said to be a place where ships and aircraft have mysteriously disappeared.

Colin Kaepernick started his career backing up Alex Smith. Kaepernick became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith was injured. He remained the starter, taking the team to the Super Bowl, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens, and the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
"Marnie" is a 1964 psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising, a non-personal form of marketing, uses sponsored messages to promote products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, advertising messages are not tailored to individuals. It reaches audiences through various channels, including traditional media like newspapers, television, and radio, and new media such as websites and text messages.
"Private Lives" is both a 1930 three-act comedy of manners written by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, (February 10, 1894 – December 29, 1986) was Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957 to October 19, 1963.

Aristotle (384-322 BC), a Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira, studied at Plato's Academy in Athens from age 17/18 to 37 (c. 347 BC). After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and became the tutor of Alexander the Great in 343 BC at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is a former arms dealer. He is also a musician, inventor, and entrepreneur.  He invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. In his rookie season, he won a championship and was named NBA Finals Most Valuable Player. He led the Lakers to four more championships in the 1980s. Johnson retired in 1991 after announcing he had HIV, but returned to play for the Lakers in 1996.  Johnson has numerous business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D, a comedy rock duo from Los Angeles, California, consists of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. Since forming in 1994, they have released three albums: *Tenacious D* (2001), *The Pick of Destiny* (2006), and *Rize of the Fenix* (2012). The band rose to fame in 1997 after starring in their television series and touring with major rock bands.

James VI and I ruled Scotland as James VI and England and Ireland as James I until his death in 1625. Though he ruled both England and Scotland, they remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments and laws. James I advocated for a unified parliament which he achieved in Scotland but not in England where he faced difficulties including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605.

Big Brother 18, the 2017 season of the British reality show, will be hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley.  Marcus Bentley has been the narrator of the show since it premiered in 2000.  He is a well-known British actor and voice-over artist, known for his Geordie accent.  He left Channel 4 in 2011 to continue narrating Big Brother when it moved to Channel 5.

The Free State of Saxony, a German state, shares borders with Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is Germany's tenth largest state (18,413 km2) and sixth most populous (4 million people). Saxony is known for its wine region, one of the northernmost in Europe, and one of only two located in former East Germany.
East End Park, located in Cincinnati, is a former major league baseball park.  "In the End" is a song by the band Linkin Park.
Mel B., signed with Virgin Records, started her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back," which featured Missy Elliott.
Noah Cyrus is the daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra, a 1994 Indian action thriller film, starred Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. Released on July 1, 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995.  The film's soundtrack was highly successful. Raveena Tandon replaced Divya Bharti, who died during production.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure.  "Hourglass" is also the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and his directorial debut with the film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
"A View to a Kill" (1985), the fourteenth film in the James Bond series, marks Roger Moore's seventh and final performance as the fictional MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua, the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, makes up most of western New Guinea.  Previously known as Irian Jaya, and before that West Irian or Irian Barat, it once encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus died, likely of natural causes.  However, rumors spread that his wife, Livia, poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez debuted in music in 1999. In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week. After her second divorce, she had a high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck. During that time she released her third studio album and starred in the movie Gigli, which was a flop.  She then married longtime friend, Marc Anthony, and starred in the successful film Shall We Dance? In 2008, she gave birth to twins.  After a less successful period in her career, she returned to prominence in 2011 as a judge on American Idol and with her single "On the Floor".

Working animals are domesticated animals trained by humans to perform tasks. These animals can serve as family companions (guide dogs), provide physical labor (draft horses), or assist with agricultural tasks (milking, herding). Wild animals can be tamed and trained, but this is typically for entertainment purposes, as they often lack the desirable temperament of domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Billboard magazine publishes a record chart called Top Latin Albums, which is the most important music chart for Spanish language albums in the American music market. Billboard magazine also publishes a genre-specific record chart weekly called Regional Mexican Albums.

Vedam, a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film, was written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. The film stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

*Men in Black II*, stylized as *MIIB*, is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film.  The film stars Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shaloub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in the novel *Don Quixote*, written by Miguel de Cervantes in 1605.  He is Don Quixote's squire and provides comedic commentary throughout the novel. His pronouncements are called "sanchismos".
"The Adventures of Pluto Nash" is a 2002 science fiction action comedy film. It is an Australian-American co-production, stars Eddie Murphy in two roles, and is directed by Ron Underwood.
The world premiere of Hedda Gabler, written by Ibsen, took place on January 31, 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich. Ibsen was in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornography production company located in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born on May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club, commonly known as Juve, is a professional soccer club based in Turin, Piedmont, Italy. Founded in 1897 by a group of students, Juventus is the second oldest active soccer club in Italy after Genoa. The team's traditional home kit features black and white stripes, worn since 1903. Juventus currently plays in a 41,507-capacity stadium called Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis appeared in minor and supporting roles in film and television in the late 1990s and early 2000s.  Some of her roles included parts in the films *Kate & Leopold* and *Far From Heaven*, and the television series *Law & Order: Special Victims Unit*.

Jenna Jameson, born in 1974 as Jenna Marie Massoli, is an American entrepreneur and webcam model.  A former pornographic film actress, she is considered one of the most famous adult entertainment performers, earning the title "The Queen of Porn."  Jameson began her career in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamour model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a National Basketball Association (NBA) team. They are members of the Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was a professional wrestling event produced by Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) under the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) banner, and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). Held annually from 1983 to 2000, the event was initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually through pay-per-view.  Traditionally, JCP held major wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas at the Greensboro Coliseum.

Jack Ryan Falahee, born on February 20, 1989, is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh in the ABC legal drama "How to Get Away with Murder" and Benjamin Stringfellow in the PBS historical drama "Mercy Street."

Seohyun, born Seo Ju-hyun on June 28, 1991, is a South Korean singer and actress known for her role in the girl group Girls' Generation and its subgroup TTS.  Girls' Generation is considered one of the most popular and best-selling South Korean girl groups.  Seohyun has also starred in several musicals, including Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia.  On January 17, 2017, she debuted her first solo album, "Don't Say No," making her the third member of Girls' Generation to debut as a solo artist.

The Apple II, a family of highly successful mass-produced 8-bit home computers, was introduced in 1977. Steve Wozniak led the design, while Steve Jobs oversaw the development of the foam-molded plastic case, and Rod Holt developed the switching power supply.

A&E, formerly Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel.  It is the flagship property of A&E Networks, which is jointly owned by Hearst Corporation and Disney -- ABC Television Group, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company. Each company owns 50% of A&E Networks.

L.A. Reid has held many powerful positions at record labels including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group. He also founded Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.
"Veeram" is the title of two Indian films: a 2014 Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

"Home for the Holidays" is a horror film franchise with two installments. The first film premiered in 1972, directed by John Llewellyn Moxey and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan. The second film premiered in 1995 and starred Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Killam is an American actor, comedian, and writer born on April 1, 1982.
"The Sex Factor" is an online reality TV series, produced by xHamster, wherein eight men and eight women compete to become porn stars.
John Dolmayan, born on July 15, 1973, is a songwriter and drummer. He is Armenian-American but was born in Lebanon.
Island Records, a British-American record label, is part of Universal Music Group (UMG).
Sikkim is a state located in northeast India.

Douglas on August 27, 1858, was part of a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas, who were running against each other for the United States Senate from Illinois. The debates, which occurred in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, were largely attended due to the importance of slavery at the time.

"Easy A" is a 2010 American teen comedy film. It was directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. The film stars Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (1941-present) is an American author known for writing gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica.  She published her first novel, Interview with a Vampire, in 1976 and wrote sequels to the novel in the 1980s.  Although she received mixed reviews early in her career, her popularity with critics and readers grew in the 1980s.  Rice was married to poet and painter Stan Rice from 1961 until his death in 2002.
Camden, New Jersey had a population of 77,344 at the time of the 2010 United States Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey.
The Canyons is a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader and written by Bret Easton Ellis.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also called The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates took place in seven towns across the state of Illinois.

Homer, known in ancient Greek as  Ὅμηρος [ hómɛːros ]  (Hómēros), is believed to be the author of *The Iliad* and *The Odyssey*. These epic poems are considered essential works in the canon of ancient Greek literature. Separately, *The Thicket* is a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL sniper, was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a Texas shooting range.

Audioslave was a band made up of Soundgarden's lead singer, Chris Cornell, and the members of Rage Against the Machine: Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, was made up of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.  Brad Wilk, known for playing in both bands, also played for the band Greta and, as of 2016, plays for the band Prophets of Rage.

Janelle Monáe (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. In 2010, her first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, was released by Bad Boy Records.  This concept album was a sequel to her first EP.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town located in East Carroll Parish, Louisiana. The University of Mississippi has a student body with 55% being undergraduates and 60% from Mississippi. 23% of students are minorities, and international students come from 90 nations.
The second season of the series Flaked, containing six episodes, will premiere on June 2, 2017.  This is a renewal from its previous season which aired July 2016.

Aaron Burr served twice in the New York State Assembly, was the Attorney General of New York from 1789-1791, was a U.S. Senator for New York from 1791-1797, and became vice president of the United States.

The Soyuz is a spacecraft designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s for the Soviet space program and remains in service today.  The Soyuz spacecraft was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program.  The Soyuz replaced the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko was a student at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City. His teacher was Jerry Robinson, an artist famous for his work on the Batman comics.

Renegades, Rage Against the Machine's fourth studio album, was released in 2000. Following the album's release, the band broke up due to internal conflicts. Lead singer Zack de la Rocha went solo, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell (formerly of Soundgarden). Audioslave released three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella.

The S&P BSE SENSEX (S&P Bombay Stock Exchange Sensitive Index), also called BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index. It features 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on Bombay Stock Exchange, including Tata Motors. Tata Motors is listed on BSE,  National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is located on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It has a population of 92.7 million, making it the 14th most populous country in the world. Vietnam is bordered by China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has had one of the world's highest economic growth rates.  However, Vietnam remains one of four remaining one-party socialist states that officially espouses communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film. It was written and directed by John Gatins. The film was Gatins' directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was an Indian socialist revolutionary who became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement. His acts of violence against British rule in India, and his execution at age 23, made him a popular figure after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana is an Indian actor who debuted in the 2016 Hindi-language film *Dangal*, a biographical sports drama directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starring Aamir Khan.

James VI and I, born James Stuart, reigned as King of Scotland as James VI and King of England and Ireland as James I.  Although he ruled both Scotland and England, they remained separate states with their own parliaments, judiciaries, and laws. James VI and I supported combining the Scottish and English parliaments into a single entity. His reign encountered numerous challenges in working with Parliament.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand actress known for her roles in television series such as *Shortland Street*, *Xena: Warrior Princess*, *The Cult*, *Legend of the Seeker*, and *Wentworth*.  She has also appeared in films, including *Separation City*, and the Australian series *Rake*.
Rob Sheridan is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer. He is best known for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.
David Spade starred in the movie *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*. The 2015 American comedy was directed by Fred Wolf and written by Wolf and Spade.
Angela Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Lady Gaga's album *Artpop* received mixed reviews from critics. However, the album was a commercial success, debuting at number one in the United States with 258,000 copies sold during its first week. *Artpop* was Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the U.S. The album sold 2.3 million copies worldwide, making it the ninth best-selling album of 2013.
Stadium Arcadium, released in 2006, was the fifth and final album by the Red Hot Chili Peppers to feature guitarist John Frusciante. Frusciante left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, the Prime Minister who implemented Thatcherism policies, remains a controversial figure.  She is regarded as one of the most influential politicians in British history, though debates about her policies continue.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author.  Aside from his work in music, he has written weekly columns on a variety of topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, in addition to acting, also narrates commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and is the third largest city in Spain. Its population is approximately 800,000. The Valencian Community, sometimes called the Valencian Country, has a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million, making it the third largest metropolitan area in Spain.
Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The television series "Make It or Break It" officially concluded with its third season, which ended on May 14, 2012. The announcement of the show's cancellation occurred on April 26, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR), a sub-field of computational linguistics, enables computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It combines linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.  Applications for this technology include voice user interfaces like voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, and search. Industry leaders such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Apple, and Amazon use deep learning methods in their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf, born January 26, 1952 and died January 4, 2012, was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded San Diego Comic-Con International, originally named Golden State Comic Book Convention, in 1970 and served as chairman beginning in 1970.  Other founders of the San Diego Comic-Con, formerly known as San Diego Comic Book Convention, include Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger and Mike Towry.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film, Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee.

Northern Ireland’s Rory McIlroy shot a third consecutive five-under-par 67 to tie for third place with Thailand’s Kiradech Aphibarnrat in the Turkish Open.  McIlroy trails the leaders, South Africa’s Jaco Van Zyl and France’s Victor Dubuisson, by one stroke.  This tournament is part of the Race to Dubai title, for which McIlroy currently holds a substantial lead over second place Danny Willett.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain's main opposition group, al-Wefaq, believes dialogue is crucial for Bahrain's future but demands concrete solutions and a representative from the royal family. He highlights the Crown Prince's reformist stance, contrasting it with hardliners opposing concessions. Salman acknowledges the disillusionment of young protesters but advocates for collaboration with reformists within the royal family, citing a previously agreed-upon seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy, which was disrupted by the GCC troop intervention. He urges stronger US and UK pressure on the Bahraini government, advocating for public condemnation of human rights abuses and the release of imprisoned opposition leaders for a meaningful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after a period of illness. He was celebrated for founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it for three decades and producing over 200 CDs. Notably, he conducted the AAM in recording the complete Mozart symphonies using period instruments, a first.  Hogwood's legacy includes his significant contributions to historically informed music, his mentorship of musicians who went on to lead orchestras globally, and his dedication to letting the music speak for itself.  His passing drew tributes from colleagues and fellow musicians who recognized his immense talent, generosity, and impact on the world of music.

Homicides in Scotland reached a record low in the year ending March 2016, with 57 cases recorded. This is the lowest number since 1976 and half the number from nine years prior. Sharp instruments, primarily knives, were used in 51% of homicide cases. While the majority of perpetrators had an unknown alcohol or drug status, 31% were confirmed to be under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Despite the positive trend, concerns remain regarding the rise in sexual and violent crimes, including attempted murder and serious assault.

Despite scoring the first goal and having enough chances to win, Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland.  The loss was Sunderland's first loss in the Premier League this season. Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe believes the team's inability to score goals lately is not due to a lack of confidence, citing their six goals scored against Hull prior to the last two games.

Australia's policy of mandatory detention of migrants arriving by boat has been called "brutal" and "inhumane" by the New York Times.  The newspaper further stated that the policy stands in stark contrast to Australia's prior welcoming stance towards refugees.  In response, Mr. Abbott defended Australia's policy, citing its effectiveness and drawing a parallel to the ongoing migrant crisis in Europe.  Mr. Abbott suggested that the only way to prevent further tragedies like the death of Alan Kurdi is to adopt a similar hardline approach.  However, Mr. Abbott drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups for his comments comparing IS to the Nazis.  While condemning IS for their horrific crimes, the Executive Council of Australian Jewry stated that such acts cannot be equated with the state-sanctioned genocide perpetrated by the Nazi regime.

The US has suspended talks with Russia that were aimed at ending the Syrian Civil War. The US stated that Russia, in failing to uphold a ceasefire agreement in Aleppo, was responsible for the present violence against civilians and aid workers. Russia expressed regret at the US's withdrawal and stated that the US had not fulfilled its own obligations in Aleppo, namely improving the humanitarian situation.  The US maintains its commitment to coordinating counterterrorism efforts with Russia in Syria.

A report by Policy Exchange, backed by Downing Street, proposes selling high-value council homes in expensive areas when they become vacant to fund the building of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. The report argues that this could generate £4.5 billion annually, potentially creating the largest social house building program since the 1970s. The proposal suggests that while social housing would still exist in expensive areas, there would be less of it, as selling 28,500 vacant properties annually could raise £5.5 billion, which, after paying off debt, would leave £4.5 billion for new construction. However, critics argue that this would displace low-income families from affluent areas, leading to segregated communities.  The Labour Party criticizes the proposal, suggesting a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes instead.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old resident of Swansea, passed away at his home. While measles was confirmed, further testing is needed to determine if it was the cause of death. Swansea is currently experiencing a measles epidemic, with 942 cases reported.
