The Electoral Commission recommends a cross-check system be implemented to reduce duplicate voter registrations.

At a ceremony in Chester celebrating eight years of the Mercian Regiment, Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, was promoted to lance corporal.  He received this honor from Brigadier Andrew Williams, the colonel of the regiment, for his "good behavior".  Lance Corporal Derby XXX is the 30th mascot ram for the regiment, a tradition dating back to the mid-19th century.  He officially joined the regiment in 2014 and even has his own army number and salary.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a thrilling game characterized by a dramatic Liverpool comeback. Down 2-0 early after a dazzling offensive showcase from Dortmund, Liverpool scored three unanswered goals to take the lead before Dortmund tied the game 3-3. In injury time, a late goal from Dejan Lovren secured the victory for Liverpool. The win embodied the fighting spirit instilled in the team by manager Jurgen Klopp, who urged his team to continue believing in themselves even when trailing by multiple goals. The victory, while showcasing Liverpool's offensive firepower and resilience, also highlighted defensive vulnerabilities that will need to be addressed in the future.  The win evokes Liverpool's improbable 2005 Champions League victory and may be a sign of more success to come under Klopp.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis announced a plan to share Brexit negotiation analysis with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland on a monthly basis.  Scottish Brexit Minister Michael Russell agreed that this was a good first step but insisted that the UK government needed to be more transparent about its goals for Brexit negotiations, specifically regarding whether it would seek to remain inside the single market and the customs union.

Thirteen cloned sheep, including four (Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy) that are genetic duplicates of Dolly the sheep, are being studied at the University of Nottingham to determine if cloned animals age normally.  This research is considered critical to the future of cloning because Dolly the sheep died at age six and a half from a virus and osteoarthritis.  Scientists are specifically looking for signs of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis in the cloned sheep through regular joint x-rays, full-body fMRI scans, and physical examinations.  The results of the study are expected to be released soon.

Shutter Speed, the favorite to win, won the Musidora Stakes for trainer John Gosden and jockey Frankie Dettori.  Shutter Speed will be raced in the French Oaks instead of the Epsom Oaks.  Stablemates Enable and Coronet will race in the Epsom Oaks.  Gosden may choose to not race Cracksman in the Dante Stakes due to concerns over the ground.

The value of the pound sterling experienced significant volatility due to polls indicating a higher likelihood of the UK voting to leave the European Union.  Investors, concerned about the economic impact of a potential Brexit, reacted strongly, causing drops in the pound's value against other major currencies and impacting stock markets globally. Despite this, Leave campaigners maintain that a weaker pound would benefit UK exporters, citing recent figures showing a narrowing trade deficit driven by increased exports.

Braintree Town, a part-time team, lost to Barrow, who are on a nine-game unbeaten run, after a goal in the first five minutes.  Despite the loss, which is their third in a row, manager Cowley remains positive, calling their achievements so far "remarkable" given that they are still in sixth place, just outside the playoffs.

Starting in April 2015, local councils in Northern Ireland will be responsible for making decisions on planning applications in their areas. Currently, this power rests with the Planning Service. Proponents, like Michael Corr of PLACE, believe that this change will give local councils the opportunity to implement their own community and development plans. However, others, like James Orr of Friends of the Earth, are concerned that this shift in power could lead to discrimination and unfairness, similar to what occurred in the 1960s with the allocation of public housing.  There are also concerns about the close relationships between developers and political parties and the lack of transparency surrounding political donations.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie, belonging to Sarah Nisbett, was shot three times by an air gun in NiddryView, Winchburgh. The cat survived but had to have a leg amputated. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information to contact them. They are also using this incident to advocate for the licensing of air guns, a measure that was rejected by 87% of respondents when the Scottish government proposed it last year.

Liverpool has signed Belgium international Christian Benteke for a club-record fee. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 appearances for Aston Villa, is Liverpool's seventh signing of the summer. Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has been eager to bolster his attacking options after a disappointing 2014-15 season in which the Reds only finished sixth in the Premier League.

Tablet usage in schools is increasing, and while they are viewed favorably by students and educators, there is no conclusive evidence that they improve academic performance.  Tablets are believed to increase student motivation and family engagement, and are viewed as a necessary part of a 21st century education. While no causal link can be made between tablets and academic improvement, educators in the study reported a positive impact from tablet use.

The exhibition, Growing Up in the City, at the Museum of Liverpool, features 25 photographs depicting the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. The photographs illustrate how childhood has evolved over the century and how special occasions were celebrated. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History at the Museum of Liverpool, also highlights the differences in children's lives, with some depicted as playing while others worked.  The exhibition runs until September 25th.

Torquay United have signed center-back Myles Anderson, 27,  and striker Ruairi Keating, 21. Anderson joins from National League rivals Barrow, while Keating joins from Finn Harps.  Torquay, currently four points above relegation, hope the pair will bolster their chances of survival.

Bolivia passed a law that lowers the minimum working age to 12 with parental permission. The Vice President, Alvaro Garcia Linera, stated that while this seems at odds with international law, the economic realities of the country, one of the poorest in South America, necessitate the change.  The law, which also increases penalties for crimes against children, is facing scrutiny by the International Labour Organisation to determine if it violates international child labor regulations.

After experiencing symptoms such as chest pain, nausea, and fever, actress Rosie O'Donnell searched online for "women's heart attack symptoms."  She then took aspirin and saw a cardiologist the following day, who discovered a 99 percent blockage in one of her arteries.  O'Donnell had suffered a "widow maker" heart attack.  She cautioned women to recognize the symptoms of a heart attack and to call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a 17-year-old from Harrow, was fatally stabbed at a party in Kenton on Saturday evening.  Although the party was well-run, a group of youths who were denied entry were involved in an altercation that later resulted in the stabbing of Che in a nearby alleyway.  A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder, as well as two boys, aged 15 and 16.  A 14-year-old was also arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark noticed their cancer survival rates were lagging behind other European countries due to long wait times for diagnosis, especially for cases that were not initially obvious. To combat this, they created a three-pronged approach: fast-tracking patients with obvious cancer symptoms, establishing diagnostic centers for patients with vague symptoms to receive a range of tests quickly, and creating "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms unlikely to be cancer, allowing for quick identification of the rare serious case. This system has led to better organization and, importantly, better survival rates, demonstrating how improved organization can lead to better patient outcomes.

Powys Council will take over responsibility from the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in overseeing estate agent activities in the UK. The council will handle cases referred by local trading standards departments, issuing warnings and bans to agents who violate the Estate Agents Act. This new responsibility will provide Powys council with £170,000 per year.

The Nuffield Trust, commissioned by NHS Employers, explored how to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce to address staff shortages.  The review found nurses already filling in for doctors and pharmacists, and highlighted areas experimenting with expanded staff roles. While this could help with doctor shortages and address the changing nature of care, the Nuffield Trust acknowledged funding would be needed.  Unions cautioned against viewing this as a quick fix, emphasizing the importance of doctor training and the need for funding to support training courses for expanded staff roles.

A road closure on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath, due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays for commuters and bus services. The road reopened at 14:00 GMT, and bus services are expected to be back to a normal schedule by the evening commute.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that a proposed tidal lagoon project would result in the death of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the company behind the project, disputed these figures, stating that their own modeling estimated a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality. NRW defended its assessment, claiming it was based on the "best available evidence" and expert analysis. They stated they had shared information, data, and methodology with TLP over an 18-month period.  The Welsh Government expressed support for the project while acknowledging the need for clarity from the UK government on its stance.

Northern Ireland's Department of Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities for both government and private sector organizations. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board to benefit the entire agri-food industry in Northern Ireland, which employs almost 100,000 people.  While Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomes the announcement, she recognizes that this new body will have implications for other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public to help plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon. The planting is part of a UK-wide project to plant millions of trees to commemorate the centenary of WWI.  The trees planted at Brackfield Wood will specifically honor the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in the conflict.  The Woodland Trust will provide the saplings and advises volunteers to wear welly boots or stout footwear.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award. The book was praised by judge and Radio Times TV editor Alison Graham, for being "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story". Ann Cleeves, Shetland and Vera writer and this year's festival programming chair, said the panel felt Hilary's book,  Someone Else's Skin, was "so finely written and tightly written". The book is a thriller that tackles domestic violence and so-called honour crime. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Cleeves praised Paretsky for creating a "strong female protagonist"  at a time when it was "pretty well unheard of" and for "chang[ing] the way that readers thought about female writers".

Worcestershire County Cricket Club is excited to announce the return of New Zealand cricketer, Mitchell Santner, for the 2017 season.  Santner will rejoin the Rapids following June's ICC Trophy in England.  His 2016 season with Worcestershire was cut short due to a broken finger sustained in his second game.  Director of Cricket, Steve Rhodes, is optimistic about his return.  In other news, Australian pace bowler, John Hastings, signed in August as the main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, died in a hit-and-run incident in Kiev in 2008. Although his wife, Ganna Ziuzina, claimed it was an accident, the coroner ruled his death an unlawful killing, citing overwhelming circumstantial evidence. Pring's family believes Ziuzina orchestrated his murder to inherit his wealth.  Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than Pring, met him online and married him quickly. She has since sold his assets and refused to cooperate with the inquest. While Ukrainian police initially closed the case, they reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011, though it remains inactive.

Charlie, a young boy from Merseyside, UK, requires T-Cell Therapy, an experimental treatment unavailable in the UK, at Seattle Children's Hospital. After a third relapse in April, this is his only remaining treatment option. The family was prepared to fundraise for the expensive treatment but received an email Wednesday from the hospital stating an anonymous donor has offered to pay for Charlie's treatment in full.  Charlie's treatment will begin as soon as possible.

Apple will implement an optional two-step verification security feature to prevent third-party software from stealing users' photos. This measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to their phone, in addition to their username and password, when accessing iCloud from a new device. Without the code, users cannot access iCloud or make purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. While this security measure effectively thwarts the hacking software used in recent celebrity photo leaks, some experts argue that Apple should make two-factor authentication the default setting for enhanced security.

Mark Wright, a 30 year old and runner up in the 2011 season of *I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here*, is finalizing a deal to buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club. If completed, this deal would make Wright a club director. Billericay are currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division.

Iain Wright, Hartlepool MP, sent a letter to Mr. Ashley, requesting his testimony regarding the treatment of workers at Mr. Ashley's company, Sports Direct.  The Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Mr. Wright, offered several dates for Mr. Ashley to appear publicly at Westminster, but Mr. Ashley declined all dates.  If Mr. Ashley fails to respond to the letter by March 21st, the committee may hold him in contempt.

Ilya Yashin, a colleague of Boris Nemtsov, recently completed Nemtsov's report, "Putin. War".  The report alleges that Russian President Vladimir Putin has been waging war in Ukraine for his own benefit. Although Russia denies the accusations, the report provides evidence that Russian soldiers were sent to Ukraine under Putin's orders to help pro-Russian rebels.  The report also reveals that Russia has spent 53bn rubles on the conflict.  Despite the readily available information on the internet, many publishers were afraid to work with the material and it is unclear how many people are interested in learning the facts.  While many Russians are aware of their country's involvement, they believe Moscow is supporting those who wish to be independent of the government in Kiev.  However, the opposition accuses Putin of masterminding and directing the war to boost his failing popularity.

Craig Nelson, 34, from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. A post-mortem examination concluded that he died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, First Minister of Wales, is upset that he was not allowed to collaborate with Prime Minister Theresa May on the letter she sent to Donald Tusk initiating Article 50. Jones feels that Wales, along with Scotland and Northern Ireland, has been continuously disrespected by the UK government during the entire Brexit process. Although May claims that the UK government will work to determine which powers should be devolved to Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland from Westminster, there are concerns about what those powers will be, and whether or not they will include adequate funding.

Two cars were damaged during an attack on police officers in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night.  Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin stated he was “appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community.” Police are asking parents to be aware of their children’s whereabouts.

American Apparel’s board of directors stated that former CEO, Dov Charney, engaged in behavior that violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy, including inappropriate emails and racial slurs.  The board maintains that this conduct makes him unfit to be rehired in any capacity at the company.  Mr. Charney is currently involved in litigation with American Apparel, alleging defamation against the company and its chair. He claims the accusations against him are false and an attempt to extort him.  A restraining order is in place preventing Mr. Charney from making negative public statements about American Apparel or attempting to remove board members.

The Great Britain basketball team will play their only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017 against Greece at the Copper Box Arena in London. The game will be available to watch on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30-19:30 (BST).  This is a chance for GB to get revenge for their 92-64 loss to Greece earlier this month, though Greece will be missing three players from that game. Following the game against Greece, GB will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament as their final warm-up for EuroBasket.

The release of the first iPhone was a pivotal moment in technological history, revolutionizing mobile phones and how people use technology. Before the iPhone, phones were primarily used for calling and texting. The iPhone, with its user-friendly interface, allowed people to perform various tasks, such as browsing the internet, sending emails, and taking photos, with ease. This new device transformed industries, particularly photography, by making high-quality cameras accessible to everyone. While other companies like Amazon and Google are currently leading the way in innovation, it was Apple's iPhone that marked the beginning of the mobile connected era.

Four cats, including seven-month-old Meereen, have died in the last seven days near Victor Avenue, in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, after ingesting antifreeze.  Another cat died two weeks prior, and the RSPCA are unsure if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate.  The RSPCA urge residents to be sure that all pesticides and chemicals are stored safely, especially antifreeze, which is commonly used in cars this time of year.

Although Greece is expected to receive a new bailout of €86 billion, the Syriza government will have to implement more austerity and liberalization measures.  These measures come despite Syriza's previous stance against such actions and have caused a further decline in the already struggling Greek economy.  In order for the bailout to be successful, creditors would need to ease Greece's debt burden and avoid triumphalism over Syriza's capitulation.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell on the television program *EastEnders*. Kemp’s return to the show coincides with the departure of Barbara Windsor, who plays Peggy Mitchell; Peggy will succumb to cancer in the spring.  Grant will reunite with his brother Phil to be with their mother during her final days.

Alice Ruggles was stalked by Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon.  Dhillon was later found guilty of her murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.  Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, stated that they and Alice did not realize the seriousness of the situation.  The Ruggles have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust in hopes of using their daughter's story to promote awareness of the dangers of stalking.

The French firm EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C power plant, but the UK government has delayed its decision on the project. Critics are concerned about potential environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign ownership, as one-third of the funding is from Chinese investors. Proponents argue the project is necessary to meet energy demands and climate commitments, and will create jobs and benefit the nuclear industry in both countries. EDF acknowledges the financial risks but maintains the project is viable.

A newly-designed divorce application form for England and Wales requests the name of the third party involved in adultery cases, which family lawyers advise against as it increases conflict. Although it's stated that providing the name is not mandatory, the form's design might encourage applicants to do so, potentially leading to complications and delays in the proceedings. While some applicants might see this as an opportunity to confront the third party, judges generally disapprove of involving them in divorce cases.

While the forestry industry in Wales is worth more than £450m annually, commercial forestry organizations are struggling to plant trees for timber due to an emphasis on environmental concerns.  Although ministers support the industry, conflict arises from a desire for more native trees and accessibility for recreation, which conservationists argue against.  The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social factors in forestry development, as evidenced by its Glastir scheme, which encourages woodland planting. However, Confor, a forestry industry representative, argues that the focus on environmental aspects hinders commercial forestry and calls for less bureaucracy in creating new woodland areas to meet timber demands.

A boy was struck by [something] in Coatbridge and sustained serious injuries. The incident occurred on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 4:40 p.m. Emergency responders transported the boy to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

During World War II, the Arctic Convoys delivered supplies from Britain to northern Russia, facing German attacks and treacherous conditions. The convoys resulted in the deaths of thousands of Allied seamen. In recognition of their bravery, surviving veterans were awarded the Ushakov medal, a Russian honor for those who demonstrate courage defending Russia, despite initial opposition from the British Foreign Office.

A report by HM Inspectorate of Probation found that offenders sentenced to unpaid work often complete very few hours, and many are let off if they do not attend. While the intention of unpaid work is to provide a "tough" alternative to imprisonment, organizational issues make it difficult to get offenders to work on time. Inspectors found that the work was often viewed simply as punishment, missing the opportunity for rehabilitation. The Ministry of Justice says it is taking action to implement the report's 15 recommendations, which include reducing how often offenders are turned away from work and creating objectives that match their circumstances.

Comedian Russell Brand has been accused of hypocrisy for living in a luxurious home while advocating for economic and political revolution to help the poor. Brand has defended himself against these accusations in the past, stating that he believes in change and that he plans to share his wealth, though he acknowledges that systemic change is necessary. He also points out that attacking him personally does not negate the issue of economic disparity.

Dr. Venter, a controversial figure in genomics, is known for his rapid sequencing of the human genome, outpacing a government-funded project. His company, Celera Genomics, achieved this by focusing on active gene sequences. Despite criticism for his approach to data sharing, Venter's wealth allowed him to establish the J Craig Venter Institute. This institute, after years of work, created Synthia, a synthetic life form. Venter's other projects include an ocean expedition to collect and sequence marine microbial genomes, aiming to understand gene evolution and function. He believes synthetic microbes could revolutionize industries, potentially reducing reliance on oil and mitigating environmental damage.

A survey of approximately 1,000 parents in England, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, found that school lunches played a role in encouraging children to try new foods.  80% of children participating in school lunches had tried a food they hadn't had at home, with 50% of parents reporting that their child requested foods eaten at school be cooked at home.  Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while eggplant, chickpeas, and spinach were less favored.  Rob Rees, Trust chairman, believes school meals are a valuable tool in expanding children's diets, while Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton observes that the desire to fit in at school can positively influence food choices.  Currently, 40% of English primary school children and slightly fewer secondary school children eat school lunches, which now adhere to strict nutritional guidelines.

Alvaro Morata, a 23 year old striker for Spain and Juventus, may be transferred back to Real Madrid.  The buy-back option was part of his 2014 transfer agreement after playing for Real Madrid for four seasons.  During his two seasons with Juventus, Morata helped the team win two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias.  Additionally, he played in two Champions League finals - 2014 as a substitute when Real Madrid won and in 2015 scoring in the 3-1 loss against Barcelona.  Before joining Juventus, the 6'3" striker started with Real Madrid at 18 years old and scored 10 goals for that La Liga team.

Kelvin Wilson, age 30, signed with Nottingham Forest for £2.5m in August of 2013 from Celtic. He had previously played for Forest for four seasons before signing with Celtic. He was released in May.  This was his second time playing for the team, making 51 appearances during his time there. He has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant, is selling its unprofitable US chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa, a private equity company.  Tesco will loan Yucaipa £80m as part of the deal, which will see 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees transfer to the new business.  While Tesco will incur a £150m cost disposing of the Fresh & Easy brand, they have the option to buy back into the business should it become profitable.  The sale represents an effort by Tesco to stanch losses from the chain, which has operated 200 stores across the American Southwest since 2007.
A man faced racial abuse, but overcame it. He thought about representing France, but is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

A new study presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting shows that the glaciers in the French Alps have decreased by 26% in the past 40 years.  The study, conducted by Marie Gardent and her colleagues from the University of Savoie, used data from map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs to assess the area of roughly 600 glaciers in the region. The team found that the glaciers covered 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s, decreasing to 340 sq km by the mid-1980s and 275 sq km by the late 2000s.  The southern sectors of the French Alps have been impacted the most, with glaciers in the Belledonne Massif almost entirely gone. The glaciers in the northern French Alps have been less impacted due to more precipitation, cloud cover, and higher elevation.

The Scotland women's national football team is on the verge of qualifying for a major tournament for the first time. They are currently in first place in their qualifying group, and a win against Iceland would all but guarantee their spot in next summer's European Championship.  Many of the players in the national team play in professional leagues, with several playing for top clubs in England, Sweden, and the United States.  Forward Lisa Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, believes that the experience these players are gaining abroad is beneficial to the national team.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger known for his Wings Over Scotland platform, was arrested in England following harassment allegations made by a woman in London.  Campbell maintains that the allegations pertain solely to some of his tweets, which he states were not threatening, and are still publicly visible. He accuses the media of reporting the incident in a way designed to incite speculation.  The police investigation is ongoing, and Campbell has been released on bail.

Peta suggests Skegness replace its mascot, Jolly Fisherman, with a fish and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice". They claim Jolly, while seemingly innocuous, promotes animal cruelty. Skegness's mayor disagrees, stating Jolly is a beloved symbol representing happiness, not cruelty.  While the suggestion will be presented to the council, the mayor believes "if it isn't broken, we won't try and fix it."

The Scotland rugby team defeated the Georgia rugby team by a score of 59-16.  Scotland dominated possession throughout the match, with Georgia scoring their first try early in the first half and their second try midway through the second half.  Scotland's coach Vern Cotter was pleased with his team's performance, praising their ball retention and counter-attacking.

Widnes Vikings defeated Castleford Tigers by a score of 38-12.  Tries were scored by Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van (2), Chris Bridge, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor for Widnes. Paddy Flynn scored 3 tries and Larne Patrick and Luke Gale each added a try for Castleford.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37 year old who was held at Guantanamo Bay on suspicion of terrorist group affiliation since 2002, was released after a US review board concluded he was not a threat to the US.  He will now spend at least a year in a rehabilitation center in Kuwait.  Mr. Odah maintains that he was in Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid.  His release brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo Bay down to 148.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, was observed with a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade of 400 people, and a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. The day's events hold special significance for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians honoring the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars, particularly the Gallipoli landings. The eight-month campaign, one of the bloodiest of the war, saw allied forces attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.  The ceremony concluded with prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom.

Leigh Clarkson, age 30, is set to make his debut for St Mirren against Alloa on Saturday.  The seasoned player, capped twice for Scotland, joins the Championship side eager to contribute his experience and fitness to improve the club's standing in the league.

Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan, who assured workers that he would honor existing agreements.  Previous pension plans will be unaffected and Unite understands that the final salary pension scheme closed in 2004, replaced with an alternative.  Boparan plans to return the company to profitability by investing in the business, saving costs, and using spare capacity to process chicken.

The new Cowes ferry has been plagued with problems since its launch on May 14th, including breakdowns, groundings, and a suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency.  In response to these issues, the council has ordered an audit of the project and made the crossing free until July 2nd.  Local businesses, already impacted by a six-month closure, are requesting compensation for lost revenue.  While acknowledging the ferry's difficult beginnings, Councillor Ian Ward believes the "teething problems" will be resolved, citing the rectification of electrical issues and ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage.

While the UK fishing industry feels optimistic about the opportunities presented by Brexit to regain control over UK waters, the House of Lords European Union Committee advises caution. The committee warns that the industry may be a low priority for the government during Brexit negotiations and that continued access to European markets may come at the price of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. The report also highlights potential challenges such as the need to retain elements of the CFP and the risk of fragmented fisheries management post-Brexit.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, was removed from the teaching profession after downloading images of young boys in erotic poses over a ten year period.  The General Teaching Council Scotland determined that Geaney's actions violated children and were incompatible with being a registered teacher. Due to the duration of his offense and lack of evidence showing attempts at correcting his behavior, the panel deemed him unfit to teach and prohibited him from re-registering for two years.

A large fire occurred at the Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited waste facility on Duncan Street on March 2nd.  The fire caused travel delays due to its proximity to train lines.  The Environment Agency in conjunction with the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, revoked the operating permit for the facility.  The revocation goes into effect August 7th, barring any appeal by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited.  The company will be required to remove all waste from the site.  The cause of the fire is undetermined.

Syria has missed the deadline to hand over its chemical weapons stockpile, blaming attacks by terrorist groups on shipments headed to Latakia.  Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad claims that Syria is, however, committed to the UN-backed plan to destroy its chemical weapons, despite concerns that the June deadline will not be met.  The Syrian government also denies reports that rebel groups have seized Aleppo's central prison, claiming instead that soldiers and security forces had "thwarted" the attack.

England beat Pakistan by 330 runs in the second Test at Old Trafford to level the four-match series at 1-1. Joe Root, who was promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq said his team are short of confidence after only two of their players passed 50 in the first two Tests of the series. The third Test at Edgbaston gets underway on 3 August.

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is reviewing the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales.  The review will utilize evidence from pensioners, families, care providers, and public bodies to highlight both positive impacts of quality care and negative impacts of poor care. The goal of the review is to understand the realities of residential care in Wales and enact changes that ensure the best quality of life for older people.  While Care Forum Wales supports the review, they are disappointed that the advisory panel lacks a representative with experience living in, working in, managing, or owning a care home.

Paul Sheerin, former player for the Aberdeen Dons, has returned to the club as manager after a comprehensive search.  He replaces Neil Cooper as manager.  Sheerin spent the last four years as player-manager at Arbroath, where he led the team to their first national trophy and a Scottish Third Division title in 2011.

Swansea City are looking to appoint a new manager after Bob Bradley was sacked.  The club want to move quickly with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement the rumored first choice.  First team coach Alan Curtis believes the club has strayed from the "Swansea Way" since Michael Laudrup left in 2014.  Curtis feels the constant managerial changes have hurt the club.  Despite that, Curtis believes the current squad is good enough to stay up.

Dr. Venter, a controversial figure in genomics, is known for his rapid sequencing of the human genome, outcompeting public efforts. His career, marked by a sense of urgency stemming from his time as a medic in the Vietnam War, has been dedicated to accelerating genomic research. He pioneered techniques to decode genes faster, leading to the sequencing of the first complete genome of a free-living organism. His private company, Celera Genomics, completed the human genome sequence in 2001, alongside public efforts. Despite criticism for his approach to data sharing, Dr. Venter's work has significantly advanced genomics. His current focus is on creating synthetic life forms, which he believes hold the potential for revolutionary applications, such as developing alternative energy sources and mitigating environmental damage.

A report by the Sutton Trust, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group, warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short when compared to other European countries, such as Germany. The report highlights that only 20% of apprenticeships in England are level three (equivalent to A-level) compared to 90% in Germany. Additionally, the report found that since 2010, over half of apprenticeships in England have been below level three and aimed at those over 25, with a mere 10% being level two apprenticeships. The Sutton Trust proposes an expansion of apprenticeships, increasing to 300,000 new opportunities annually, with the majority being level three and lasting a minimum of three years.

Dame Sarah Storey, a British Paralympian, secured victory in the C5 time trial at the Para-cycling Road World Championships. This win marks Storey's 21st world title across her career in both cycling and swimming.  Already holding 22 Paralympic medals, Storey aims to add to her collection at the upcoming Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.

Hereford United Football Club has been expelled from the Football Conference due to their inability to pay their football creditors a total of £148,000 by the final deadline of June 12th.  Their spot in the Conference Premier has been given to Chester FC.  The club also owes over £70,000 in back taxes.  The club's financial woes began with their relegation from the Football League in 2012, after which they saw a significant drop in attendance and revenue.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international soccer after earning 61 caps for England since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, playing only three minutes in Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 appearances since 2004.

Christopher Hogwood, conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), has died at his home in Cambridge following an illness. He was considered a leading figure in the early-music movement and worked with many orchestras around the world. Hogwood founded the AAM in 1973 and served as its director for 30 years, during which time the orchestra recorded over 200 CDs. He was also a tutor at Harvard University, an honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University.  Hogwood's colleagues remember him as a generous and brilliant musician who was passionate about historically informed music.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is being protected, has been removed from mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping. His parents requested a place for him at a special school but were told all the schools were full.  The family is still waiting for a place as of September.  The boy's mother shared their story with BBC's Good Morning Ulster programme, expressing her concerns about her son's isolation and the capacity issues in the special needs school system.  The family was recently told an extra classroom assistant was hired at a local special school and their son may be able to start in the upcoming weeks.  The Education Authority stated they are unable to comment on individual cases, but are reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland and working to ensure places are available.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has launched a takeover bid for Rodney Parade, home to Newport Gwent Dragons.  Newport County currently has a lease to use the ground until 2023, with primacy over fixtures.  The WRU takeover will be voted on May 9th, with County chairman stating their current lease would be honored.  The WRU's plan to install an artificial surface would be against Football League rules.  Relegation for County would be a massive blow to both fans and the city of Newport.

This is the story of a man who was kidnapped at age 15 by the RUF rebels during the civil war in Sierra Leone. He endured many horrors and was forced to commit atrocities as a soldier. He eventually escaped and found his life's purpose helping others. When the Ebola crisis struck, he and his fellow volunteers risked their lives to educate the public and support those affected. He believes in the power of young people to change the world and is dedicated to investing in their future.

The Wedgwood Museum, facing the auction of its 80,000 piece collection to pay off the Wedgwood pottery firm's pension debt, will retain its collection thanks to a successful fundraising campaign.  The collection will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and loaned to the Wedgwood Museum for display.

Mark Wright, age 30, may buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club.  The club is currently in eighth place in the Isthmian League Premier Division.  Wright previously played in a lower-level football league.  The club is currently owned by Glenn Tamplin, who recently spent a large sum of money to acquire former England player Paul Konchesky.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute with a goal from Jamille Matt. Colchester United equalized in the 17th minute with a goal from Kurtis Guthrie.  Colchester United's Sean Murray received a red card in injury time.

Fawley Waterside developers plan to transform the disused Fawley power station, which closed in 2013 after more than 40 years in operation, into a “merchant city” development.  The plans include a marina, housing and restaurants, as well as fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth.  The centerpiece of the development will be a petal-shaped glass structure in the center of the 198-meter-high chimney.   Building could start in 2018.

Great Britain's Mark Latham secured the bronze medal in the men's scratch race at the UCI Track Cycling World Championships in Hong Kong. Latham, who finished behind Adrian Teklinski of Poland and Germany's Lucas Liss, earned Great Britain's second medal of the championships. Great Britain's women's team pursuit, composed of Elinor Barker, Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson, finished fifth in their heat and did not qualify for a medal opportunity. Katy Marchant, who won bronze in the women's sprint at the 2016 Rio Olympics, was eliminated in the first round.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell in the soap opera "Eastenders." He agreed to the role so that the Mitchell brothers could be reunited with their mother Peggy, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, one last time before the character dies.

Tottenham Hotspur manager Mauricio Pochettino states Spurs must improve if they want to compete for the Premier League title after losing 2-0 to Liverpool.  He added that a lack of desire and inability to handle pressure are why his team struggles on the road against top-six rivals.  Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy believes Tottenham should utilize tactics that have proven successful against top teams, such as employing a back three.

In Nigeria's elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) secured victory in 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking a significant setback for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. This follows the APC's presidential win the previous month, with Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated on May 29th. The PDP's losses were particularly notable in key northern states. However, the PDP retained control in Rivers State, a crucial oil-producing region. Notably, the APC did not secure victory in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, potentially posing challenges for the incoming president in terms of oil revenue and militant activity. The elections, while marred by some instances of violence, were regarded as more peaceful compared to previous years, suggesting a positive trajectory for Nigeria's democracy.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19th to the 22nd, will be utilizing a new augmented reality app this year. The app will allow attendees to access information, videos, and band interviews via their phones and tablets.  Additionally, the app will allow people worldwide to experience the festival remotely.

Ofsted found five Birmingham schools, including Park View and Oldknow, to be inadequate and potentially promoting extremist views.  The schools in question will have their funding terminated by the Secretary of State unless they address breaches, such as the segregation of boys and girls and failure to promote a “broad and balanced curriculum,” by July 4th.  Parents of students at the schools in question are upset by the reports, calling them biased and claiming the schools are being used to push others’ agendas.

Honey Rose, an eye specialist, is on trial for gross negligence manslaughter after the death of her patient, Vincent Barker.  Rose conducted a routine eye exam on Barker, but allegedly failed to diagnose swollen optic discs.  The prosecution argues Rose's alleged failure to refer Barker for further investigation led to his death.  Rose denies the charges.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with another man and filming it. He then sent a sexually explicit clip from the encounter to the victim's sister. He was found guilty at the Dundee Sheriff Court and the case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh.  Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and given a sentence reflecting the seriousness of his crimes.

Ireland scored 165-5 in their Twenty20 cricket match against Afghanistan in Greater Noida. Stuart Thompson led Ireland with 56 runs.  Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad scored 56 and 47 runs respectively, leading Afghanistan to victory at 171-4. The two teams will play again at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona FC has made an additional tax payment of  €13,550,830.56 in relation to Neymar's transfer to the club.  Although the club insists they met their initial tax obligations, they made the payment to cover any discrepancies in the interpretation of the contracts involved in the transfer.  This comes after a judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to investigate the transfer for tax-related crimes.

Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are being held by Thai police in connection with the murders of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge. The two men are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery.  Although the suspects have allegedly confessed to the killings, there are concerns regarding the police investigation, specifically about the DNA evidence and the treatment of the suspects.  A team of UK detectives were sent to Thailand to review the investigation and will be returning to the UK to compile their report and update the families.

The Scotland Women's national football team is on the verge of qualifying for their first major tournament. Currently undefeated in their qualifying group, a win against Iceland at Falkirk Stadium would secure their place in next summer's finals in the Netherlands.  This would be a historic achievement for the team, who have come close to qualifying in recent years but fallen short in playoff losses.  Forward Lisa Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, emphasizes the team's focus on taking each game step-by-step, acknowledging the tough competition from Iceland.  Evans also highlights the positive impact of more Scottish players competing in top leagues abroad, bringing valuable experience and skills to the national team.

Apple has updated its security protocol to prevent third-party software from stealing users' photos. The new two-factor authentication system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device in addition to their username and password. This code will be required to access iCloud and make purchases in iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. Without the code, users will be blocked from these services. However, users can regain access to their accounts with a 14-character recovery key if they lose their trusted device. While this security feature was previously an option, Apple will now encourage users to enable it to increase security and prevent data breaches.

The six highest-spending parties in the 2014 UK European Parliament election spent a total of £9,347,087.  The UK Independence Party (UKIP) won the election, spending £2,956,737, or 68p per vote. The Labour party was second, spending £1,027,339, or 26p per vote. The Conservative party spent £2,980,815, or 79p per vote. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575, or £1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. The Scottish National Party (SNP) spent £267,372. All but the Labour party spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

Torquay United have signed central defender Myles Anderson from Barrow and striker Ruairi Keating on a free transfer. Anderson is a 27-year-old journeyman footballer, while the 21-year-old Keating joins from Irish club Finn Harps.  The Gulls, who sit just above the relegation zone, hope these two signings will help improve their form.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, died after winning the Cotswold Chase.  The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) stated the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," noting that this is a rare condition that can occur in horses without underlying health issues.  Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia, causing overheating and unsteadiness, but he had not exhibited these symptoms at his most recent race.  While there were questions about a link between his death and previous overheating, the report concluded that the haemorrhage was the cause of death.

The passage describes the farewell speeches given by presiding officer Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, and Duncan McNeil as they prepare to step down from their positions in the Scottish Parliament. Salmond reflected on his time as first minister, stating that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse” and highlighted the importance of the parliament assuming greater responsibility for Scotland’s governance. McNeil used his speech to advise that the parliament should learn from Westminster’s committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny.

Emma Watson will star as Belle in a live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. The film, directed by Bill Condon, will also star Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou.  Rounding out the cast is Oscar-winner Emma Thompson, who will play Mrs. Potts, and fellow Oscar-winner Kevin Kline as Maurice. The film will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce whether charges will be brought against 23 suspects in the Hillsborough disaster. The announcement will be made at a meeting with victims' relatives in Warrington, where Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS, will inform the families of the decisions.  The charges relate to the Operation Resolve investigation into the causes of the disaster and an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into the conduct of both South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police following the disaster.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced a high number of attempts to throw packages over the prison walls.  A resident who lives nearby claims to have witnessed four such incidents in two weeks.  The prison is said to be "flooded" with contraband such as mobile phones and synthetic cannabis.  The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the problem, stating that while staff works hard to prevent contraband, more needs to be done. New laws have been enacted that could result in up to two years of jail time for those caught smuggling packages into prisons.

Brian Wright, 55, struck 72 year old Sylvia Blackburn with his car as she was working as a lollipop lady outside of Bedford Road Lower School.  Mr. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and is pleading not guilty to the charge of causing serious injury by dangerous driving.  The trial is ongoing.

Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary studies. Though disappointed, Muir prioritizes completing her degree. She remains optimistic about competing in future events, including potentially the World Indoor Championships in March and at least two more Olympic Games.

In December 2000, 22 year old Trevor Deely went missing while walking home from a Christmas party.  A new search of a three-acre, wooded area in Chapelizod, Dublin began early on a Saturday morning.  The search will involve excavations and is expected to last a number of weeks.  Earlier that year, a team of six detectives began a complete review of Deely's disappearance.  Using specialized technology, CCTV footage from the night of Deely's disappearance was enhanced.  The footage shows Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street.  Detectives believe that this man is the same man captured on CCTV following Deely a short time later.  Police are asking for this man to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after a two year absence due to injury, defeated Stanislas Wawrinka in four sets at Wimbledon.  del Potro will face the winner of the Lucas Pouille and Donald Young match.  Also, Nick Kyrgios defeated Dustin Brown in five sets and will face Feliciano Lopez in the third round.  The winner of that match will play either Andy Murray or John Millman in the round of 16.  Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also had victories, defeating Benjamin Becker and Juan Monaco respectively.

Tunisia and Morocco will be allowed to compete in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after both avoided potential bans. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 tournament, while Tunisia were disciplined for their furious reaction to a controversial penalty decision that eliminated them from the same competition. Morocco's ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, while Tunisia apologized to the Confederation of African Football (CAF) after a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou.

The McLaren Formula 1 racing team has experienced both incredible successes and dismal failures throughout its history.  They achieved dominance in the 1980s with Honda engines and drivers like Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and again in the late 1990s with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines. However, the team has also faced periods of decline, including scandals and a recent slump due to problems with Honda power-units. Despite the challenges, McLaren's CEO, Ron Dennis, remains optimistic about the team's future, believing that they will soon return to their winning ways and break Mercedes' current dominance in the sport.  Fernando Alonso rejoined the team in 2015, seeking his third championship and placing his faith in McLaren and Honda's partnership. Only time will tell if their belief will be enough to restore McLaren to its former glory.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was ordered to close for three months after a sudden death on the premises.  The court found that alcohol was being served outside of licensing hours as late as 04:49 BST, while paramedics were called to the bar at 06:00 BST. License holder Colleen O'Neill was fined £3,000 and James Thomas was fined £1,000 for allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, making eight 3-pointers and scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers. This surpassed his previous record of 272 three-pointers in a single season. In other NBA action, Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds to help the Chicago Bulls overcome a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were tricked into giving a free-kick masterclass to YouTube star Bas van Velzen.  The players initially believed that van Velzen was a competition winner, but soon realized he was a skilled footballer. Van Velzen, who is known for his free-kick videos, impressed the players with his abilities.  He described the experience as "amazing" and enjoyed "pretending that [he] was n't very good at free-kicks." Van Velzen concluded the prank by presenting Balotelli with a t-shirt referencing the striker's famous "Why Always Me?" slogan.

A study published in JAMA Oncology found that women diagnosed with the BRCA1 gene mutation who had an oophorectomy (removal of the ovaries) after being diagnosed with breast cancer had a 62% lower risk of dying from breast cancer. This protective effect was observed immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The study's authors call for further research on the effects of oophorectomy in women with the BRCA2 gene mutation, as the survival benefit was not observed in this group.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The accident occurred around 10 am on Norfolk-Southern property.  The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, was carrying 166 passengers; none were injured.  After a delay of approximately three hours, the train continued on its route.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia while working for the Medellin cartel.  Toro was promised US citizenship for his help in prosecuting criminals like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega.  Due to declining health, Toro retired and was subsequently denied citizenship by the DEA.  He is currently facing deportation.

ICANN, the US body that regulates internet addresses, is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd.’s practices regarding its “.sucks” domain name. Vox Populi is selling “.sucks” domains for around $2,499 a year, primarily to celebrities and companies like Kevin Spacey and Visa, who are looking to protect their reputations. An advisory panel, made up of industry groups and companies like Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay, referred to the practice as a “shakedown scheme,” as the average consumer can secure a “.sucks” address for just $10 a year.  ICANN, in turn, has contacted the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada’s Office of Consumer Affairs to investigate whether Vox Populi’s actions are illegal.

In 1988, the body of a baby boy was found in a pond in Weasenham St. Peter, Norfolk.  The mother was unidentified, and the cause of death could not be determined.  He was buried in the churchyard.  In 2015, DNA evidence led police to the mother, who stated that she had concealed the pregnancy and the baby was stillborn.  She was initially arrested for infanticide, but that charge was dropped.  A second post-mortem examination supported the mother's statement.  The case was closed with no charges expected.  The baby was reburied on the 26th anniversary of his discovery and named Peter after the church where he was laid to rest.

Kristopher Hicks, 23 at the time, suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving taxi driven by Michael Young, 56, in Bath, Somerset. Mr. Young mistakenly believed Mr. Hicks was going to "do a runner" and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank.  Mr. Hicks objected, and after being driven for almost a mile at over 20 mph, jumped from the vehicle, sustaining brain injuries that require round-the-clock care. The High Court ruled that Mr. Young unlawfully imprisoned Mr. Hicks, who is entitled to damages. While the final amount is pending, it is estimated to be hundreds of thousands of pounds, reflecting 50% of the Hicks family's requested amount.

Multiple tornadoes were reported across Kansas on Wednesday night, with one near Goddard and three near Aetna. The storms also brought heavy rain, hail, and wind damage to Missouri, particularly in Potosi. The severe weather is expected to continue across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and the Great Lakes region on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold plans to defeat Lyoto Machida by being aggressive and pushing the pace of the fight. Rockhold believes Machida will be challenged by his speed and will tire as the fight progresses. Machida, while acknowledging Rockhold's strengths as a fighter, believes if he can implement his fighting strategy, he will be victorious. Both fighters believe a win will earn them a title shot.

An 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, mistakenly landed his light general aviation aircraft at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without deploying the landing gear. The plane skidded along the runway on its belly, damaging the propellers.  Remarkably, the pilot managed to take off again and flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has stated that Yaya Touré will remain with the club for the remainder of the season, despite Touré and Pellegrini's performances being underwhelming.  Touré has failed to meet expectations this season, and Manchester City are rumored to be listening to offers for the midfielder.  Pellegrini also stated that captain Vincent Kompany will likely miss the rest of the season due to injury.  In other news, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has cautioned left-back Aaron Cresswell against following in the footsteps of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who joined Manchester City but were seldom used.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive dubbed the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will remain in the UK after his seven-year prison sentence for being a member of the Cosa Nostra expired in October 2014. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed.  Rancadore, who fled to Britain in 1995, was convicted in absentia in Italy and lived under the assumed name Marc Skinner.  The Italian government is expected to withdraw its European arrest warrant, and Rancadore will be discharged from extradition proceedings.

Mr. Mole, ridden by A.P. McCoy, is one of three favorites in the seven-horse Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown. This will be McCoy's last Grade One race, though his final rides as a jockey won't be announced until Friday. McCoy rode Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February, after which he announced his retirement. Other contenders include Special Tiara, Sacre, and Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia who was murdered in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter for the first time.  Her husband at the time had advised her against it, wanting her last memories to be of Marcia alive.  Marcia's body was found after 33 days; she had been strangled and sexually assaulted. The case went unsolved until 2006 when DNA on Marcia's clothing matched that of Jerome Sydney Barrett, who was serving time for the 1975 murder of Sarah Vannatta Des Prez.  He was found guilty of second-degree murder in Marcia's case and sentenced to 44 years.

Rory McIlroy is seeking his first Masters win at the Augusta National to become the sixth player to win all four major titles.  McIlroy believes that winning at Augusta would make him a complete player and that it is unthinkable that he would never win the Masters. Although he has not had much success at Augusta in the past, his collapse in 2011 taught him a lot about himself and his game, which led him to win his first major title at the US Open two months later.  Last year, despite distractions from his personal life, McIlroy used golf as his sanctuary, and he hopes to do the same at Augusta this year.

This week's trending stories include: four rainbows appearing in the New York sky; the Chinese government cracking down on strippers at funerals; Robert Downey Jr. walking out of a Channel 4 interview after being asked about his private life; the dangers of the new #kyliejennerchallenge (lip plumping by sucking on a jar); a 102-year-old woman revisiting her past with the help of filmmakers; a promposal rejection that sparked accusations of racism; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp's transformation for his role in Black Mass; a pregnancy announcement referencing the Fresh Prince of Bel-Air; and a military dad photobombing his son.

New figures reveal that 272 children with disabilities caused by fetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England in the past year, according to the Health and Social Care Information Centre.  However, the World Health Organization estimates the actual number of children affected by fetal alcohol syndrome to be much higher, around 7,500 every year, or 1 in 100 babies born in the UK.  The National Organization for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome emphasizes the seriousness of this under-diagnosed problem, stating that children born with the syndrome do not recover and highlighting the lifelong impact of learning, behavioral, and physical disabilities.

31-year-old Shaun Andrew McKerrey attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores on March 15th.  The masked robber brandished an axe and demanded cash from the cashier. Shop owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerrey, knocking him to the floor.  While the men wrestled, Dhillon's wife, Sam, hit McKerrey twice with a baseball bat, disarming him.  Police arrived and arrested McKerrey, who plead guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court.  McKerrey was sentenced to six years in jail.  Known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" in his youth, McKerrey has a history of criminal activity dating back to age 12.  By age 15, he had been arrested 80 times.  His past convictions include aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary.  He was given his nickname in the 1990s after being arrested 80 times in 1995 and 45 times during the 36 weeks he managed to stay out of prison in 1998.

Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley, have been charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault after an incident that occurred at the Shearwater naval base in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The four men were playing in a hockey tournament at the time. They have been released on bail over £2,000 each and are required to stay at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax until their trial. They must also surrender their passports and are prohibited from contacting the victim or the six witnesses. The sailors will continue to work for the Royal Navy and draw their current pay. The investigation is ongoing and additional charges may be filed.

Four-year-old RJ Jackson, from Las Vegas, suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, a rare genetic condition that causes red, scaly skin.  Because people mistake his condition for a burn or other injury, RJ's mother, Valerie, has been accused of child abuse, even being confronted by police while shopping.  Valerie says she and RJ are used to the stares and ignorant comments, but she wants people to be more aware of Netherton's Syndrome.  She says RJ is a happy and bubbly boy who loves to play, despite the pain and discomfort of his condition.

Protein World, an online fitness store, is facing backlash for their "Are You Beach Body Ready?" advertisements featuring bikini-clad model Renee Somerfield. Critics argue the ads promote an unhealthy body image and make women feel pressured to look a certain way.  Despite receiving over 200 complaints, the Advertising Standards Authority is currently reviewing the campaign. Although Transport for London is removing the posters as scheduled after a three-week run, the company acknowledged considering public response for future campaigns.  Protein World remains defiant, engaging in social media debates and defending their marketing strategy.

Train companies in the UK are facing criticism for planning fare increases up to 87%, just days after political parties pledged to freeze or cap fare prices.  The increases affect unregulated fares, including off-peak and advance purchase tickets. First Great Western, one company planning increases, argues the increases align the North Cotswolds route with other services and offer cheaper advance single ticket options.  Virgin Trains, another company increasing fares, stated their increases primarily affect "Virgin Trains-only fares," which are at least 20% cheaper than competitor fares, and their overall fare increase is 1.65%, below the industry average.

John Young, a 66-year-old retired soldier, has been left blind in one eye after being struck in the face with a brick. The attack occurred at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester, while he and his wife Elaine were writing thank you cards.  The couple had been married for three weeks. Mr. Young was attacked when he opened his front door to confront a group of youths who had been throwing stones at his property. Police are investigating the incident but say there appears to be no motive. They are appealing for witnesses to come forward.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a one-year contract extension with the county. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to injuries sustained in a road accident that resulted in the death of his father. After a successful recovery and return to form, Poynton is now contracted through the 2016 season.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw is now cancer-free after battling an aggressive form of neuroblastoma for over a year. Diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, Harley used a ninja turtle mask he decorated to feel brave during radiotherapy. His story garnered international attention, even prompting Nickelodeon to send him gifts.  After 80 days of chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley is cured but will undergo regular checkups. Neuroblastoma is a rare childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually, usually under the age of five.

Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa manager, believes Jack Grealish should focus on performing well for his club before making a decision about his international career. Grealish, who has impressed with his recent performances, is eligible to play for both England and the Republic of Ireland. His father agrees that club football should be his priority at this time.

Private jet travel is a growing trend among the wealthy. Landing fees for these jets can reach thousands of dollars, with the most expensive airports concentrated in Japan. Haneda Airport in Tokyo charges the highest fee at £4,559, followed by Narita International Airport (£3,728) and Kansai International Airport in Osaka (£3,594). Other airports in the top 10 for landing fees include Toronto Pearson, Darwin International, Bristol, Chubu Centrair, Dublin, and LaGuardia in New York.

Katie Gallegos took her two dogs, Cooper and Daisy, to get ice cream. A video of Cooper eating his ice cream in one bite has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs the treat. However, she defended her actions by stating that Cooper is in good health and that Daisy, due to her size, only gets a few licks. Gallegos also shared that she gives her dogs the occasional "pup-uccino" from Starbucks, which consists only of whipped cream.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock, signing a three-year deal. He was initially assistant manager under Allan Johnston, but stepped up in February when Johnston quit. Locke has lost just once in seven games as manager.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, claims her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, was threatened with suspension from Seminole County Elementary for wearing Doterra essential oils. The school reportedly finds the scents, which include lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, distracting. Kemp argues that the oils help her son stay calm and focused, and she plans to contest the decision. However, the Lake County School District has stated that they will not suspend Logan, deeming it a "health issue."

On Wednesday afternoon, a fire broke out at the Sandpiper Complex in Westhampton Beach, New York, destroying 90 condominiums.  The blaze was so intense that it melted paint on nearby buildings.  While the cause of the fire is unknown, it is being investigated by fire officials.  The complex is a holiday home used by residents between May and November.  Fortunately, no injuries were reported.

Though approaching 89 years old, Queen Elizabeth still enjoys riding her fell ponies, particularly Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park.  The Queen has ridden since age four, when she received her first pony, Peggy. The Queen favors riding in a silk scarf instead of a helmet, as she has her whole life.  While a niggling knee injury has reduced her riding time, the Queen remains an enthusiastic equestrian and is often seen at the Windsor stables.  The Queen also breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court,  a breed favored for its gentle nature and looks.

A 55-year-old man named Leon Yeaman was killed after being punched in the head by his neighbor, 28-year-old Phillip Pama, following a noise complaint. Pama, a shift worker who was sleeping at the time, confronted Yeaman who was allegedly being loud in his yard around 9 pm. During the altercation, Pama punched Yeaman once, resulting in Yeaman's death. Pama was granted conditional bail and the case is ongoing.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's football manager, is a devout Christian who prays and speaks to God every day, though he only attends church when he feels the need or is in Portugal. He emphasizes that his conversations with God and his church visits are strictly about his personal life and never about football. Despite his arrogant demeanor in the professional sphere, Mourinho considers himself a good person, citing his strong family and friend relationships and his charitable endeavors. He acknowledges that his competitive nature in football leads him to push people, sometimes causing friction, but maintains that his professional life is only one facet of his multifaceted personality.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1st.  Barker, age 91, hosted the first price-guessing game, then turned hosting duties over to Drew Carey.

Secret Service Agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested and charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property after allegedly attempting to break into a Washington D.C. residence at 12:30 a.m. on Friday.  The Secret Service has revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave.  This incident follows two other recent scandals involving misconduct by Secret Service agents.

Atif Saeed, a photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, left the safety of his car to capture close-up photos of a lion in a safari park.  He was able to take a few pictures before the lion heard the camera's shutter.  The lion then charged at Mr. Saeed, who narrowly escaped by retreating into his car.  Mr. Saeed stated that he would not attempt to get so close to a lion again.

The NYPD released the image of a heart tattoo bearing the name "Monique" in hopes of identifying a woman found deceased on a Brooklyn street on March 22.  The woman, aged 25-45 years old, was discovered unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend and pronounced dead that evening.  The cause of death is pending a medical examiner's report. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck. After returning to New Zealand from the UK in 2009, they could not afford to buy property. The home is solar-powered and features wood and steel construction. They have a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and get water from a nearby spring. Their first power bill was only $25. In total, the project cost them around $25,000.

A study by Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class scored 30 points higher on literacy tests than students who used iPads individually or who did not use iPads. Blackwell, who conducted her research with 352 students at a Midwestern suburban school district, concluded that “collaborative learning around technology,” rather than collaboration alone, was a significant factor in the students’ success.  Blackwell will present her findings at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without back legs in Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation. Nicknamed "super pig," the piglet has learned to balance on its two front legs and walk. The piglet's owner, Ms. Duan, noticed the piglet's differing ability while feeding the litter. This is not the first instance of a two-legged animal gaining popularity in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also drew attention for learning to walk on its front paws.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, tire changer Todd Phillips was hit by Francesco Dracone's car during a pit stop. Phillips, who suffered a cut on his leg, was treated and released from the infield care center.  Dracone went on to finish 23rd in the race.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, after a fight in their Rio de Janeiro apartment. Severiano slammed Sena's head into the concrete 11 times and punched her in the face 10 times. He then shot her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to the murder, saying he was jealous of men looking at his wife.
