Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in Severiano's car after he crashed it while attempting to escape. He faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author, revealed in an interview with Women's Weekly Australia that her struggles with mental illness, including anxiety, brought her to a point where she contemplated suicide.  A combination of factors, including stress, her thyroid disease, a distant family, and feelings of isolation, contributed to her belief that her life was no longer worth living.  Wilson emphasized the interconnectedness of depression and anxiety and highlighted the increasing prevalence of anxiety among Australian women.  She believes that acknowledging this link is crucial for effectively addressing the negative impacts of stress and anxiety.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, faced charges of second-degree assault for striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. Prosecutors dropped the charges, citing Curtin's actions as justified, as Oregon law permits physical force against intruders refusing to leave a residence. The ex-girlfriend was found using heroin in Curtin's bathroom and refused to leave when asked.
Gemma, a pit bull living in California, was filmed being tricked by her owner into eating a piece of broccoli with her treats. Showing her distaste for the vegetable, she spits it out on the floor.

A link on HSBC's website redirected users to a pornographic site because the bank's webpage for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, last active in 2011, had its registration expire.  The page's URL was subsequently taken over by a pornography site. HSBC has since removed the link and apologized for the inconvenience. They assure the public that this does not affect the security of their internet banking services.

On Sunday morning, a 13-year-old boy named Marcus helped save himself and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, from a house fire in Clinton, Maryland. Marcus called 911 and calmly provided instructions to the dispatcher, guiding firefighters to their second-floor bedroom. Firefighters rescued the children through a window. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae, caused by the single-celled phytoplankton *noctiluca scintillans*, has been lighting up the coast of Australia, specifically in Jervis Bay, NSW, creating a neon glow.  Iain Suthers, of the University of New South Wales, explains that the algae blooms in the spring and autumn and in 90% of occasions, is caused by natural occurrences. The glow is a defense mechanism for the *noctiluca scintillans*, which is a carnivorous cell that preys on diatoms, another type of algae.

New genetic tests that determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors can spare some women from undergoing chemotherapy.  Following tumor removal surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab for screening. Within days, women can be told if they are at high or low risk of the disease returning. The test accurately identifies women with a recurrence risk as low as 5%, which is as good as or better than the odds for those who undergo chemotherapy. While chemotherapy kills cancer cells, the side effects can be difficult.  These new tests, such as Endopredict, give patients the option of forgoing chemotherapy if they are low risk. Although currently a costly private option, experts believe the NHS cost savings of not providing chemotherapy would offset the test price.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy in recent years.  Data obtained by The Sun shows that eighteen ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, had emergency evacuations for pregnant crew members. A strict "no touching" rule is in place on these vessels, suggesting the pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave.  The data also reveals that nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013 after discovering they were pregnant, as military rules prohibit expectant mothers from serving in war zones.

A drone measuring 20 inches in diameter and carrying a small amount of the radioactive material cesium was discovered on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence.  The drone was also equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle.  Japanese officials, including Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga, are concerned the incident could indicate future acts of terrorism utilizing drones at upcoming events such as the Olympics and the G7 Summit.  Currently, Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports only, but not government buildings, such as the Prime Minister's residence.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in China, brings his 84-year-old mother to work with him every day. After his father passed away and with no one else to care for her, Lu Xincai transports his mother on the back of his motorbike to his job at a bank four kilometers away.  His mother suffers from Alzheimer’s and would get lost when left alone. Lu Xincai’s employers have provided his mother with her own room, where he checks on her frequently.

A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, primarily due to increased alcohol consumption by women. Researchers believe this increase may be attributed to evolving social norms, the affordability of alcohol, increased advertising, and relaxed alcohol control policies.  In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. Excessive drinking contributes to a significant number of deaths and costs the U.S. billions of dollars annually.

The World Health Organization (WHO)  advises that Cesarean sections should only be performed when medically necessary. They report the ideal rate of Cesarean sections should be between 10% and 15%.  The current rate in England is just over 25%, more than double the rate in the early 1990s. This is due in part to women opting to have planned Cesareans due to anxiety about childbirth. The WHO warns that Cesareans can lead to infections, complications, disability, or death.  The procedure is also more costly than natural birth, costing the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to £1,665 for a natural birth.

44 year old, Michelle Filkins, was arrested on April 17th and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Filkins was found in Mark Conklin’s $800,000 summer home on Martha’s Vineyard where she had been living for at least a week, selling the homeowner’s belongings in a yard sale.  Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Bella Crooke lost her phone at a friend's birthday party. A good samaritan found the phone and turned it into the Albury Police Station.  The police officers discovered the phone was unlocked and decided to post selfies and humorous captions to Crooke's Facebook page in an effort to locate her.  The officers' posts went viral, and Crooke was reunited with her phone later that day.

A five-day-old hippopotamus died after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos. The calf's mother stayed with her herd for safety, but one of the fighting males grabbed the calf. The mother tried to save her baby, but the male hippo bit down hard and tossed the baby into the air. The baby hippopotamus died of its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom maisonette in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000. The property is considered a "bargain" as it is priced significantly lower than neighboring homes. However, the catch is that the lease only has three years remaining. While the cost per year would be comparable to renting, extending the lease could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. Despite this, estate agents are optimistic about the sale due to the property's rarity and prime location.

A computer outage at over 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada on Friday evening led to free drinks for customers as baristas were unable to process sales. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented staff from accepting credit cards or ringing up sales.  While some stores continued to serve customers and accept cash, others closed early to avoid giving away free products. Starbucks resolved the issue and announced stores would be open for business as usual on Saturday.

Rural areas in West Wales, specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, are being used for terrorist training and to radicalize Muslims.  This activity is not new, with incidents of Islamic extremism dating back to 1998 in the area.  While those involved may appear to be participating in ordinary activities, Detective Constable Gareth Jones warns that they have ulterior motives.  DC Jones stresses the importance of community intelligence in combatting these activities, urging anyone with information to come forward.

A deceased Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct, was discovered on an Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This finding is significant because very little is known about this species, which was first described in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. DNA profiling was used to identify the whale, a 5.68-meter juvenile female. The whale's skeleton will be recovered in a few years for scientific investigation and potential museum display.

This article discusses the sexism ingrained in questioning whether a woman, specifically Hillary Clinton, would be a good president, not due to her qualifications, but solely based on her being a woman. Some believe women are unfit to be president due to their hormones, using the justification that men like George W. Bush have started wars due to their testosterone. However, studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men. The article uses the example of Cheryl Rios, who states she'll move to Canada if Clinton is elected because a woman shouldn't be president, to highlight the pervasive idea that women are unfit to lead. This bias against women is detrimental to society, as equality benefits everyone. Companies with more women in leadership roles make more money, children with involved fathers are happier and healthier, couples who share responsibilities have stronger marriages, and diverse teams produce better results. The article concludes by stating that telling our daughters they can be anything they want to be is not enough; we must also combat the pervasive and wrong belief that they are unfit to lead.

89-year-old actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in *All Creatures Great and Small* and his portrayals of Winston Churchill, is selling over 200 items from his antique collection.  The collection includes paintings, furniture, weapons, books, and a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt commissioned from artist L.M. Rendall in the 1960s.  The auction will be held this Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.  Mr. Hardy, a military history enthusiast, expressed sadness at downsizing his collection.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted by Florida police in connection with the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57.  Shemansky did not show up for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead in their shared Winter Garden home.  Police were alerted after an out-of-state family member requested a well-being check. Shemansky is on parole for battery on a law enforcement officer and has a history of mental illness. Neighbors speculate that divorce proceedings may have been a factor in the murder. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) has chosen Eugene, Oregon, as the host city for the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision, which breaks from the traditional bidding process, was made to capitalize on a unique strategic opportunity to hold the event in the United States for the first time. Although Eugene lost its bid for the 2019 event to Doha, Qatar, the IAAF was convinced by a presentation that showcased the city's capabilities.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, has been sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger befriended Hassan and lured him back to his flat, where her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and his accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, were waiting to rob him. They tied Hassan up, beat him to death, and ransacked his apartment. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years.

Cesc Fabregas, despite a strong start to the season, is experiencing a dip in form during the latter half of the season, a trend observed in his previous seasons. While he was on track to break the Premier League assist record, his performance has declined, with only one assist in the last five games. Despite this, Fabregas has an opportunity to regain his form and contribute to Chelsea's Premier League title hopes, particularly given Chelsea's upcoming opponents, many of whom Fabregas has previously assisted against.

Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old Jamaican forward from Montego Bay United, has impressed West Ham coaches after a two-week trial. Beckford has offers from other European clubs, including teams in Belgium.  In other news, West Ham season tickets at Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the lowest price in the Premier League, to help fill the 54,000 seats when they move to the stadium for the 2016-17 season.

A huntman, Mike Lane, was attacked by hunt saboteurs while participating in a hunt using artificial scent. Despite providing video evidence of the assault and names and registration numbers of suspects, Wiltshire police dropped the investigation citing insufficient evidence. Lane and other hunt supporters expressed disappointment, highlighting the difficulties in prosecuting attackers who conceal their identities.

Adam Gadahn, born in 1978 as Adam Pearlman, was an American citizen and known as the mouthpiece of al Qaeda. He converted to Islam in 1995, left for Pakistan in 1998, and joined al Qaeda shortly after. Gadahn rose in the ranks, becoming their chief English-language propagandist, appearing in videos threatening attacks on the West, urging Muslims in America to commit acts of terror, and praising those who did. He was indicted in 2006 by a federal grand jury for treason and material support to al Qaeda. Gadahn was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation, though he was not specifically targeted.

A five-year-old Chinese boy, Mai Zizhuo, is captivating audiences with his remarkable basketball prowess. Videos showcasing his skills, including dribbling two basketballs simultaneously and sinking multiple hoops, have gone viral in China, drawing comparisons to basketball legend Yao Ming.  His abilities have stunned netizens, with many expressing awe and admiration for the young prodigy.

Tom O'Carroll, a former activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25. Hacked Off, a media pressure group, is campaigning for state involvement in media regulation. O'Carroll's attendance is noteworthy due to his controversial past with PIE, an organization that campaigned to legalize sex with children.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The lifestyle brand, headed up by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome collection of ten unisex pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent a day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, a safari park in Northern California, with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa. During his visit, Khan interacted with several animals, including feeding a white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions. Khan recently announced his next fight will be against Chris Algieri, former light-welterweight world champion, on May 30.

The name of Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a Palestinian teenager killed by three Israelis in July, was added to Israel's memorial wall for fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. Abu Khdeir's family objected to his inclusion on the wall, as did Almagor, an organization for victims of terror in Israel. Both argued that Abu Khdeir was not a victim of terrorism, but rather the victim of a rogue attack. Following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel has removed Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial wall and website.

A young boy was filmed following his pet cat around a garden, repeatedly using the animal as a pillow.  The cat, clearly annoyed at being used as a place to rest, would move as soon as the boy got comfortable.  Eventually, the cat went indoors. A later video showed the pair had made up.

Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer testifying for the government in a police corruption trial in Philadelphia, lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after his testimony revealed his past. Kushner testified that during a 2007 arrest, officers stole money and drugs from him. He had passed a background check when hired in 2010 because the charges were expunged, but the school was unaware of his subsequent arrests in 2011 and 2008. Kushner claims he has moved past this phase of his life.  Lawyers for the accused officers say the government’s case relies on testimony from “lying drug dealers.”

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, injured six people. The blast, caused by an oil leak in an oil storage facility, sparked a large fire that required over 600 firefighters to contain. While there were no reports of a toxic chemical spill, five people were hospitalized due to injuries from broken glass. This incident follows a previous explosion at the same plant in 2013. The plant's construction and operation have been controversial, with protests erupting in 2007 due to pollution concerns, leading to its relocation from Xiamen to a less populated area.

Jack Grealish, Aston Villa player, prefers to wear his socks low, just above his children's sized shin pads, as a superstition. Despite being told by referees to pull them up, Grealish states he will not change this habit. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, a tough game for his first start, but was happy to have finally done so.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. While no longer in a medically induced coma, Bobbi Kristina remains unresponsive, unable to respond to stimuli, and requires a tracheostomy. Despite Bobby Brown's statement that his daughter is awake and watching him, medical professionals and family representatives clarify that her condition, though slightly improved, indicates a long and uncertain rehabilitation process, with the quality of her future life unknown.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in the Fed Cup after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3 and Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets.  Russia is one win away from capturing the Fed Cup title for the first time since 2008.

New South Wales residents are bracing for more floods and damage as a new storm system, similar to the one that recently devastated the area, is predicted to hit later in the week. Heavy rain is expected from Thursday to Saturday, particularly impacting the northern parts of the state. The State Emergency Service (SES) is urging residents to prepare their homes and families for potential flooding and high winds, especially in the already hard-hit Hunter region. While the upcoming storm is not expected to be as severe or as long-lasting as the previous one, the SES is concerned about the impact on already saturated ground and damaged infrastructure.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, was hospitalized on Saturday night after fainting due to low blood pressure.  Italian media outlets incorrectly reported that Ms. Moric had attempted suicide. Ms. Moric confirmed that she was recovering at home after the accident and was never suicidal.

A recent poll indicates that the British public is hoping the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's second child will be a girl and named Diana, after William's mother.  If the baby is a boy, the favored name is James.  Other popular choices include Alice and Charlotte for a girl and Alexander for a boy.  The poll also revealed that most Britons support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bombing in Khost, Afghanistan, killed 17 and wounded 64, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon. The protest was en route to rally against the provincial governor.  The Taliban denies involvement, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

After seven years and multiple title wins with Barcelona, Dani Alves will not be returning to the club next season.  The 31 year old's agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves rejected Barcelona's final contract offer.  The three-year extension offered to Alves was contingent on him playing at least 60% of the team's matches.  Santana stated that negotiations are over and expressed her bewilderment at the club's delay in renewing Alves' contract.

Pablo Osvaldo has urged Italian soccer players Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes the duo would be a good fit for Boca, and says the fans would love to have them.  He feels that Pirlo and Totti have a South-American style of play and would be perfect for Boca Juniors.

Eighteen-year-old jockey Lewis Ferguson fell off his horse, Merrion Square, in a spectacular double somersault fall at Wincanton.  Despite the virality of the incident and a cut on his nose, Ferguson was back at work the next day, uninjured and undeterred from riding again.

James Haskell, captain of the London Wasps rugby team, celebrated the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron by posting a picture of himself in an Iron Man costume on Instagram. Haskell, who rejoined the Wasps in 2012 after stints with Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders, has played over 100 games for the Wasps and earned 57 caps playing for England.

Wide leg trousers are on trend.  They provide an alternative to skinny jeans, which have been in style for many years. To avoid being overwhelmed by fabric, pair wide leg trousers with a fitted top and heels to elongate the legs. Denim is an easy way to participate in this trend, as exemplified by Gucci. Other brands who have showcased this trend include Topshop, Celine, and Stella McCartney.

The University of Michigan canceled a screening of the film "American Sniper" after more than 200 students signed a petition objecting to the film's depiction of the Iraq War. The university received backlash for its decision and a counter-petition was created asking the school to reconsider.  The university ultimately decided to screen the film, stating that the cancellation was inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression.  As an alternative, the university will also screen the film "Paddington."

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, have been charged with animal cruelty after allegedly attempting to light a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island (off Perth, Western Australia) on April 3rd. The tourists were evicted from the island and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17th. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame.

Alice Barker was a dancer in the 1930s and 1940s, performing at notable New York nightclubs alongside stars like Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Although there were films made of her dancing, Barker had never seen them, nor did she have access to photographs or memorabilia from that time. For the first time, at 102 years old, Barker was able to see herself dance again through a video compilation of "soundies" (early music videos) put together by volunteers. Barker was delighted by the experience.

A recent study by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that a third of men and three-quarters of women in Britain never wash their own cars. Reasons for this decline include busier schedules, the prevalence of hand car washes, and the larger size of modern vehicles. While some car owners still wash their cars, particularly during holidays, it is no longer the common practice it once was.

Steven Gerrard will play his final game for Liverpool on his birthday, May 30th, in the FA Cup final against Arsenal if Liverpool defeats Aston Villa in the semi-final. Gerrard's teammate, Martin Skrtel, has praised the impact and example that Gerrard has set during his time at Liverpool. Skrtel believes that Gerrard is one of the best players in the world and that Liverpool will never be the same without him. However, Skrtel believes that Liverpool has players who can replace Gerrard and that the team will work together to fill the void.

75-year-old golf legend Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one at the Augusta National par-3 contest. This was his first ever hole-in-one at Augusta. Camilo Villegas also hit a hole-in-one on the fourth hole, and another on the eighth.  Kevin Streelman won the par-3 contest.  Rory McIlroy can complete a career grand slam if he wins his third major in succession.

Multiple tornadoes were reported across Kansas on Wednesday night, with one near Goddard posing a risk to communities. Southwestern Kansas had three reported tornadoes near Aetna.  The National Weather Service reported a possible tornado touchdown in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. More storms are expected Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73 year old Oklahoma reserve sheriff’s deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter charges for the April 2nd shooting death of Eric Harris.  Bates claims he mistook his gun for a taser while attempting to subdue Harris. The victim’s family is outraged by the judge’s decision to allow Bates to vacation in the Bahamas while they mourn and await the July 2nd preliminary hearing.  Bates’ attorney maintains his client is not guilty and looks forward to proving that in court.  Bates’ attorney released training documents to refute claims by the victim’s lawyer that Bates was inadequately trained and received preferential treatment due to his friendship with the sheriff and donations made to the sheriff’s office.

Conor McGregor has gotten a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach ahead of his July 11 fight against Jose Aldo for the featherweight title. McGregor claims that he is more motivated than Aldo, stating that Aldo "doesn't want to be near [him]" or "want [the fight] the way [McGregor] wants it."  McGregor further demonstrated this perceived disparity in motivation when he grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of his home crowd during their promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott, after chugging a beer at a function, has drawn criticism from anti-drinking advocates who believe he is promoting binge drinking and harmful stereotypes.  Critics, such as cultural studies professor Julie Robert, argue that Mr. Abbott's actions and the public's response promote a culture of rapid and excessive drinking rather than responsible social drinking.  While some defend Mr. Abbott's actions as part of Australian culture, others argue that such behavior sets a negative example, particularly given growing concerns about binge drinking.

Indiana Governor Mike Pence will decide whether or not to extend the 30-day needle exchange program, implemented on March 26th to combat the rise of HIV cases in Scott County, by early next week.  As of April 10th, there are 120 confirmed cases of HIV and 10 preliminary positive cases.  While health officials expected the number of cases to rise, the growing number could pressure Pence to extend the program beyond April 25th.  Pence, who opposes needle exchange programs, will have to weigh his position against recommendations from health officials.  State legislature is also considering a bill that would allow the 23 Indiana counties with the highest rate of Hepatitis C to establish their own needle-exchange programs.

A woman named Saskia scored an 87% on a 50-question test about the football team Arsenal, created by her boyfriend.  The test was graded with a red pen, included multiple choice, fill in the blank, and short answer questions, and instructed the test taker to read each question twice.  Saskia's boyfriend praised her score, while also pointing out areas of improvement.  Social media users who saw the exam posted online by Saskia had mixed reactions, with some calling the boyfriend a "legend" and others saying he took things too far.

Carlos Toro, a former member of the Medellin cartel, worked for the DEA for 27 years as an informant in exchange for the promise of US citizenship.  Despite his service, which included aiding in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, the DEA has not assisted Toro with obtaining citizenship. As a result, Toro is now facing deportation to Colombia, where he believes he will be killed for his past deeds.  He is currently residing in the US illegally after his temporary visa expired and is seeking a green card or passport to avoid deportation.

A 14-year-old girl in India’s Uttar Pradesh state set herself on fire after being gang raped by five men from her village.  The men are now under arrest.  The girl’s family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. She is currently in critical condition at a Delhi hospital.   This attack follows a recent ban on the documentary *India’s Daughter*, which focuses on a fatal 2012 gang rape of a student that resulted in protests throughout India.  Officials claim the film would cause further unrest.

Manchester United will face Manchester City on Sunday at Old Trafford.  Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is hoping for a win, which would put the team in contention for a top three finish in the league. Van Gaal will have to manage without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, who are both out due to injury.  Manchester United lost their previous match against Manchester City 1-0.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League game in protest of high ticket prices, which start at £64 at the Emirates Stadium.  Fans from both clubs, including Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906, organized the protest in response to the Premier League's recent £5.14 billion TV rights deal. They believe these prices are unfair to working-class fans and are driving a wedge between them and the sport.  Protests continued after the game concluded.

Star, a newborn baby from Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition. After an unsuccessful surgery to unclog her bile ducts, a liver transplant became the only option. Neither parent was a suitable match for the transplant. However, Star's maternal aunt, Shanell, who is also her mother's twin sister, proved to be an ideal candidate and donated part of her liver. The operation took place in November and, after a six-week hospital stay, Star returned home and has made a good recovery.  She will require ongoing medical care, including weekly blood and liver function tests, and lifelong anti-rejection medication.

Chelsea football players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. The challenge involved three rounds: kicking balls into the boot of a car, playing tennis over an Audi R8, and kicking balls through the top of a convertible Audi. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian won the final round. During the challenge, Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror of one of the Audis.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide in the deaths of Amanda Murphy, Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger drove his truck into oncoming traffic, hitting the couple's SUV. While prosecutors claim that Dellinger stated he was trying to kill himself at the time of the crash, Dellinger claims to have never been suicidal. His lawyers claim he was suffering from a combination of withdrawals, an overdose, and advanced multiple sclerosis. Dellinger faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit.

Lacey Spears, of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt. Prosecutors argued that Spears, motivated by a need for attention, intentionally made her son ill. They cited Spears' social media posts, where she chronicled Garnett-Paul's supposed illnesses, as evidence of her seeking attention. Spears' lawyer plans to appeal the verdict, arguing her innocence and blaming the hospital for negligence.  Garnett-Paul's father, Chris Hill, expressed his desire for Spears to be placed in general prison population, believing she would not survive.

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia a month later than expected due to the inclusion of new protections against the H3N2 and B/Phuket strains. These strains were responsible for increased flu-related deaths in Europe and the US because the previous vaccine did not protect against them.  The new vaccine is expected to be a better match against globally circulating strains.  High-risk groups will have access to free vaccines starting April 20th, but experts recommend everyone get vaccinated.

As the 150th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's assassination arrives, caretakers of his tomb face criticism from a National Geographic article that calls the site uninspiring.  At the same time, budget cuts threaten the tomb's upkeep, worrying those who believe in its historical importance.  Supporters of the site disagree with the article's assessment and point to the recent renovations, such as the interior lighting upgrades and waterproofing efforts, as proof of the tomb's significance.

Many early 2000s fashion trends are being revived by celebrities and fashion enthusiasts. Some of these questionable trends include bucket hats, camouflage print, oversized clothing, Ugg boots, denim short shorts, velour tracksuits, colorful sunglasses, corsets, and harem pants. While some celebrities are embracing these trends, many people who experienced these styles the first time around are hoping they will not make a full comeback.

This week's trending stories include: a photo of four rainbows over New York City, China's crackdown on strippers at funerals, Robert Downey Jr.'s uncomfortable interview when asked about his private life, the dangers of the new #kyliejennerchallenge (lip plumping using a jar), a 102-year-old woman's prom dream fulfilled, a prom proposal rejection that sparked accusations of racism, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in the live action "Beauty and the Beast,"  Johnny Depp's transformation for his role in "Black Mass," and creative pregnancy and photobomb announcements.

Serena Williams was presented with a cake at the Miami Open in celebration of her 700th career victory after defeating Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3.  Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-final.  Halep defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5 to advance.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist known for her outspoken nature and advocacy for free speech, was tragically shot dead in her cafe, The Second Floor (T2F), in Karachi, Pakistan.  Known for her work promoting human rights, women's entrepreneurship, and open dialogue, Mahmud recently hosted a controversial discussion group focused on the disappearances and alleged abductions in Baluchistan, a topic often silenced within Pakistan. Despite previous death threats and the event's cancellation at a prominent university due to its sensitive nature, Mahmud remained undeterred, choosing to host the discussion at her cafe.  Her death, mourned by many across the country, has left a void in the fight for progressive values and open dialogue in Pakistan.

Mangu Ram is a West Pakistan Refugee (WPR) living in Jammu, Kashmir.  He is one of around 100,000 WPRs who fled to the region during the partition of India in 1947.  Due to a pre-independence law, WPRs are not considered citizens of Kashmir, denying them the right to own property, vote, or work for the state government.  With the recent election of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) into Kashmir's governing coalition, there is hope for change as the BJP has pledged to champion the cause of WPRs and normalize their status.

Chelsea FC has made a £4 million offer for FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto.  Muto, who wants to play for a team where he can develop, is considering the offer.  Former coach Ranko Popovic believes Muto would be a good fit for Chelsea, describing him as a fast, strong, intelligent, and confident player.  Although aware of Muto, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho declined to comment on the potential transfer, but acknowledged that the club considers financial aspects in its transfer policy.

England’s rugby team should select its players from the best athletes, regardless of where they are playing, just like Australia’s team does.  Players playing overseas, such as Steffon Armitage, often improve by playing against top competition.  Not selecting the best players for the national team just because they play outside of England will hurt the team’s performance in the World Cup. England’s coach should select the team based on its players’ talent and performance.

Open Garden developers have created Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that strengthens off-the-grid networks. It functions as a beacon or booster, facilitating smoother message transmission across these wireless mesh networks. Greenstone enhances the capabilities of Open Garden's Firechat app, which allows communication without internet or mobile signals. Firechat, downloaded over five million times, utilizes the multipeer connectivity framework (MCF) feature in iOS 7 and a similar feature in Android that operates via Bluetooth. MCF enables message and photo sharing even without a signal by establishing a wireless mesh network. This network allows devices within Bluetooth or Wi-Fi direct range (approximately 30 feet) to connect and transmit data. While Firechat can relay messages across multiple devices to reach a recipient, its range is limited to around 200 feet. Greenstone aims to overcome this limitation. It acts as a hub, storing messages and transmitting them to Firechat users within its range. Currently under development, Greenstone works with Firechat within a 20-foot range and can store up to 1,000 recent messages. Open Garden is collaborating with manufacturers to finalize Greenstone's design and make it commercially available.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer, is promoting body positivity by embracing the word "fat" as a self-descriptor. She believes that "fat" doesn't have to be synonymous with "ugly" and uses her burlesque performances to challenge societal beauty standards. She feels that the more people are exposed to body diversity, the more accepting they will become.  Lillian's goal is to help others, especially young girls,  feel confident and positive about their bodies, regardless of size.

Theo Walcott and six of his Arsenal teammates (Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil) were photographed for a Lanvin photoshoot. Lanvin, Paris's oldest fashion house, has been the club's official tailor since 2013.  Walcott has spent much of the season on the bench, appearing as a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games.  Arsenal's players will wear attire similar to that in the photoshoot at the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30.

A collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on propstore.com on May 29th, 2023. The collection is worth an estimated $746,100 and includes items from films such as *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *An American Werewolf in London*, *Planet of the Apes*, *Batman & Robin*, *Hellboy*, and *Mighty Joe Young*, as well as from Michael Jackson’s 1988 film *Moonwalker* and 1983 thriller music video. Some of the items expected to fetch top dollar include alien Edgar Bug from *Men in Black* (estimated at $40,000), the Grinch costume from *How the Grinch Stole Christmas* (listed at $8,000), and the iconic Harry suit from *Harry and the Hendersons* (valued at $6,000).

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell, described by his family as a "daring, outgoing and determined" boy, died in a skiing accident in the French Alps while on holiday with his mother, sister, and brother.  Carwyn became separated from his family when his sister lost her ski on a jump. He was last seen heading toward dense woodland. Believing the boy had returned to their hotel, his mother, Ceri, searched for him before contacting authorities. Police discovered Carwyn's body, following his footprints in the snow, at the bottom of a 164ft drop.  Carwyn's family, devastated by his death, said he was an experienced skier and snowboarder who had been skiing since age three.  They expressed their grief, stating, "The family cannot explain their feeling of utter devastation with a vast void in their hearts."

15-year-old Laura Scurr developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with her weight and trying to attain a size zero figure.  At her lowest point, she ate only 100 calories a day, hid food from her parents, and lied about eating meals. Her condition worsened to the point of hospitalization after her heart rate slowed, and her body began to shut down.  Through the help of eating disorder teams and mental health services, Laura recovered. Now, she speaks out about the pressures young girls face to be thin.

Liverpool unveiled their new home kit, designed by New Balance, at Anfield. Raheem Sterling was present at the unveiling alongside teammates. This comes amidst uncertainty surrounding Sterling's future at the club after he rejected a £100,000-a-week contract.  Fans urged Sterling to stay with the club next season. Sterling acknowledged the fans' support, emphasizing their importance to the players.

Astronomers have created a high-definition map of dark matter over 0.4% of the sky using data from the Dark Energy Camera. The map, created by measuring the shapes of 130 million galaxies, shows clumps of dark matter with red indicating dense areas and blue indicating sparse ones. The project, part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey, aims to map 12.5% of the sky, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy. The team hopes to learn more about the formation of galaxies and the nature of dark energy, which is believed to be accelerating the universe's expansion.

Manchester United are attempting to acquire Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old winger who plays for PSV Eindhoven and the Dutch national team. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league appearances this season for PSV.  He has drawn interest from other clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain, but Manchester United are the frontrunners to sign him. Depay is a skilled and fast player who has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1 in a commanding victory. Tammy Abraham scored two goals for Chelsea, bringing his season total to 36.  Dominic Solanke scored Chelsea's third goal. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored Manchester City's lone goal.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that while he believes people are born with their sexual preference, he does not support same-sex marriage as a constitutional right. He said he believes marriage should be between a man and a woman and states should be able to decide their own definitions. However, he would still attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer because he cares for them.

Pablo and Ilze are a couple who have been traveling the world by bicycle for over a year. They have visited 16 countries and traveled over 7,000 miles while spending less than three euros each per day. To save money, the couple camps, uses hosting websites, and eats inexpensive foods. They plan to continue traveling by bicycle for the next several years.

A Texas couple is suing photographer James Evans of Premiere Photos for allegedly printing racial slurs on photo booth pictures from their 2012 wedding. The couple claims Evans was dismissive and told them to sue him when confronted about the incident, which they did not discover until months after the wedding. Evans denies the allegations, stating there is no evidence connecting his company to the offensive captions. The couple says they are seeking an apology, not money. Mediation is scheduled and a trial is set for July if the parties cannot reach an agreement.

England full-back Mike Brown is recovering from a concussion sustained after the Six Nations England-France game and is unsure when he will return to play. Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovery to avoid the fate of other players like George North and Johnny Sexton who are out for an extended period due to repeated concussions. Brown credits World Rugby's online modules for educating players on concussion symptoms and empowering them to prioritize their health.

Research reveals that Britons are having sex less frequently now than in the 1990s and 2000s.  Cambridge statistician Professor David Spiegelhalter suggests that increased smartphone and internet use may be to blame.  He argues that constant connectivity to work and other obligations leaves less time for couples to be together.  Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, agrees, stating that "sex just falls down our list of priorities."

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly sought after status symbols in China, are now being abandoned and sent to slaughterhouses due to an anti-corruption crackdown, breeding issues, and their unsuitability for city living. Previously, these dogs were given as expensive gifts to officials, but the government's anti-corruption drive has made people wary of such practices. Overbreeding has also led to a surplus of low-quality Mastiffs, which are now being abandoned or sold to slaughterhouses for their meat and skin.  The decline in their popularity is further fueled by bans on large dog breeds in major cities and a growing awareness that the breed is not suitable for urban environments.

A survey of 600 women in Paris revealed that all had experienced sexual harassment or assault on public transportation.  This harassment, ranging from verbal abuse to rape, often goes unreported but has significant consequences for women's freedom and sense of safety.  The report resulting from the survey highlights the need for public awareness campaigns to educate people about the prevalence of this issue and to emphasize that such behavior is unacceptable and punishable by law.

Direct Line, in collaboration with Makerversity, held a competition called #everydayfix. The competition challenged designers to create products that provide solutions to common everyday emergencies. The top three designs were Snooze, Forget Me Lock, and Nipper. Snooze is an alarm clock that connects to a user's phone and silences notifications to ensure a peaceful sleep. The Forget Me Lock is a device that attaches to a key, turning red to signify the door is locked and green to show it's open. Nipper is a small mobile phone charger that can draw power from any household battery. The designs were shortlisted from a pool of ten everyday emergencies determined by a survey of 2,000 people. The winning design, decided by the most retweets on Twitter, will be developed and funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating £500,000 to Victims First Northumbria, a charity where she is a director.  The charity's leadership includes Northumbria Chief Constable Sue Sim, prompting accusations of conflict of interest from critics like Keith Vaz, Labour chairman of the Home Affairs Committee.  While Baird defends her decision and adherence to Ministry of Justice protocols, concerns remain about potential conflicts of interest given Sim's role and Baird's oversight of the police force.  The Ministry of Justice is investigating whether any conflict of interest rules were broken, which could result in funding being ceased.

In March 2014, 53-year-old Greg Valecce was held captive for three days in the basement of 21-year-old Corry Campbell's mother's house, where he endured torture and abuse by Campbell and his accomplices. Campbell, believing Valecce had harmed his cat, Pebbles, and stolen from him, inflicted physical violence and tattooed offensive imagery on Valecce's body. Campbell's girlfriend, Sandra Ng, and friend, Carl Halin, participated in the assault, which was recorded on video. Valecce sustained severe injuries, including broken bones and psychological trauma. All three perpetrators were charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment. Campbell and Halin received 20-year prison sentences, while Ng was sentenced to 23 months. Two other individuals, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, await sentencing and trial, respectively, for their roles in the crime.

Manchester United are attempting to acquire Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old winger who plays for PSV Eindhoven and the Dutch national team. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league appearances this season for PSV.  He has drawn interest from other clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain, but Manchester United are the frontrunners to sign him. Depay is a highly touted prospect who has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea's youth team won against Manchester City's youth team with a score of 3-1. Tammy Abraham scored two goals for Chelsea and Dominic Solanke scored the third. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored the single goal for Manchester City.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated in an interview with CBS's Face the Nation that while he believes people are born with a sexual preference, he does not support gay marriage as a constitutional right. He said he believes marriage should be between a man and a woman and that the decision to legalize gay marriage should be left to state legislatures.  Rubio stated that he would still attend the gay wedding of a family member or staffer because he cares for them.

Pablo and Ilze are a couple who have been traveling the world by bicycle for over a year and plan to continue for years to come. They have traveled through 16 countries, covering almost 7,000 miles at an astonishingly low cost of less than three euros per day. To save money, the couple camps most nights, utilizes hospitality websites, and eats a simple diet supplemented by foraging and the generosity of others. They began their journey in London, traveled through Europe, and are currently in Armenia, from where they plan to continue through Asia, across the Pacific, and down the length of the Americas.

England full-back Mike Brown is recovering from a concussion sustained after the Six Nations England-France game and is unsure when he will return to play. Brown is heeding the advice of medical professionals and taking a cautious approach to his recovery to avoid the fate of other players who suffered long-term consequences from returning to action too quickly after sustaining concussions. Brown credits his awareness of concussion symptoms to World Rugby online modules that highlight the short and long-term dangers of concussion and encourage players to be honest about their symptoms.

The frequency of sexual intercourse among Britons has decreased from an average of five times per month in 1990 to three times per month in the 2000s.  One potential reason for this decline, posited by Cambridge University statistician Professor David Spiegelhalter, is the increasing intrusion of technology into our personal lives.  This, according to Spiegelhalter, leads to  busy schedules and a lack of dedicated time with one's partner.  British National Survey researcher Catherine Mercer supports the notion, adding that constant connectivity leads to decreased prioritization of sex.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly valued in China, with some fetching prices as high as £1.2 million, have drastically decreased in popularity. This decline is attributed to China's anti-corruption crackdown, which has dissuaded the giving and receiving of these dogs as gifts, and bans on owning large dogs in major cities. Consequently, many Tibetan Mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather, with some breeders even selling their undesirable dogs to these facilities.  The overbreeding of these dogs, which has led to a surplus of low-quality Tibetan Mastiffs, coupled with the realization that they are not suitable for city living, has also contributed to their decline.

Direct Line, a company based in Leeds, is running a competition called #everydayfix where they challenged design groups to create products that provide solutions to common daily problems. The top three designs, chosen from a shortlist, were created by groups from the London-based design company, Makerversity, to tackle these problems: forgetting to lock the door, needing to charge your phone on the go, and struggling to fall asleep.  The designs include "Forget Me Lock," a device that attaches to a key and indicates whether a door is locked or unlocked; "Nipper," a small mobile phone charger that runs on household batteries; and "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to minimize sleep disruptions. The winning design, determined by the most retweets on Twitter with the hashtag #everydayfix by April 40th, will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product.

Qatar Airways is headquartered in Doha and operates out of Hamad International Airport. The airline flies to over 160 destinations across the globe, utilizing a hub-and-spoke network and a fleet of over 200 aircraft.
