The severe weather also led to ferry cancellations and the closure of tourist attractions. Wind speeds decreased by Friday evening, allowing for bridge restrictions to be lifted. However, the forecast for continued blustery conditions has forced the postponement of at least one event, Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip.

Michael B. Jordan will star in the upcoming film *Black Panther*, directed by Ryan Coogler. The film will also star Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. *Black Panther* is scheduled to be released in February 2018.

The Alexandra Palace Theatre, originally built in 1875, is undergoing a £26.6 million refurbishment project to become a cultural hub with theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music.  The project will include the restoration of the theatre and adjacent BBC studios. Funding for the project comes from the Heritage Lottery Fund, Haringey Council, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, with hopes of reopening in 2018.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international soccer after earning 61 caps for England since his 2009 debut.  He was part of the England squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes in the Euro 2016.  Milner also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps at 46.

The Smith family home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a fire that started in their wood stove. The family escaped thanks to 11-year-old David Smith, who was awake and saw the flames. The fire spread incredibly fast, destroying the kitchen even as the family stood in it. Sadly, the family pets did not survive. The community has been very supportive, donating clothes and other necessities.  Mrs. Smith credits her son with saving her and her daughter's lives.

Energy drink company considering £200 million offer for West Ham United Football Club.  The current majority owners purchased the team in 2010 for £105 million and now own over 85%.  Previous rumors had circulated about Qatari and Chinese groups being interested in purchasing the team.  While it is possible a minority share will be sold to cover outstanding debt, the current owners plan to pass the team down to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards, a fan-voted award show, celebrated films and actors while promoting summer blockbusters. "The Fault in Our Stars" won best movie, with Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss with Ansel Elgort. Other notable winners included Bradley Cooper (best male performance), Channing Tatum (best comedic performance), and Meryl Streep (best villain). The ceremony also featured appearances from stars like Robert Downey Jr. and the Avengers cast, and showcased upcoming releases like "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Ultron."
St. Mirren has acquired 21 year-old Cammy Smith on loan from Aberdeen. Smith, who has five goals this season, debuted with Aberdeen in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances with the team.

Northumberland County Council is undertaking a project over the next four months to repair potholes and damage caused by heavy rain. Using Jetpatcher machines, the council aims to repair 145 potholes per day. Additional staff will be deployed to fix damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. Although the exposure was below the reportable limit, EnQuest notified the Health and Safety Executive (HSE).  An investigation prompted additional safety measures to prevent future exposure. Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety, conducting medical assessments and reinforcing safety procedures. However, concerns were raised about the handling of the incident, particularly the alleged lack of proper personal protective equipment (PPE) and the potential long-term health effects on the workers.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore will return a stolen 11th Century bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India.  The ACM purchased the sculpture in 2007 from Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to selling stolen antiquities. Although there is no concrete proof the sculpture was stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, the ACM acknowledged the confession of Art of the Past's manager.  The ACM will pursue legal action to receive compensation for the fraud.

A 4.8 magnitude earthquake hit 35km north of Lucca, Italy. While there were no immediate reports of damage or injury, the tremor was felt as far as Milan and Florence. The quake caused power outages and phone lines to be down in the Garfagnana area. Schools in the area were evacuated. This is not the first earthquake to affect the region. In May of the previous year, the area experienced two earthquakes that resulted in over 20 deaths.  Italy is prone to earthquakes, one of the most notable being the 2009 L'Aquila earthquake that killed almost 300 people.

Austin Grant, a 62 year old grandfather from Sheffield, has successfully grown a pineapple.  While he was initially unsure about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate for growing pineapples, he was overjoyed to discover that the fruit was growing.  However, as of September 8, 2016, the fruit was still not ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the release of Grand Theft Auto V for PC until March 24th to allow for further testing and polishing of the game.  The game will support 4k resolution and up to triple monitor configurations.  Online heists will be available on consoles prior to the PC release.   Minimum specifications required to run GTA V have been released.

Artist, Charles Simpson (age 76), was awarded the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his painting *Squint (19)*.  The piece, which had been shortlisted in 1991, was lauded by judge Ansel Krut as "quite extraordinary". Simpson intends to use the prize money to fund future artwork.

Unidentified assailants attacked the offices of Turkish newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, both of which support President Erdogan's government. The attacks occurred at night, almost simultaneously, and involved gunfire that shattered windows. No casualties were reported. Police are investigating but no arrests have been made.

A 24-year-old soccer player who was under contract with the Stags has been signed to the Mariners on a free transfer. He previously played for Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. This is the first signing for the Mariners under their manager, Bignot.

Gareth Southgate, who is currently the interim manager for the England national team, will be evaluated on his performance in the upcoming World Cup qualifier against Scotland and the friendly against Spain.  Arsenal manager, Arsene Wenger, who has been rumored as a possible replacement for Southgate, stated that Southgate needs to be given the opportunity to demonstrate his competency as a manager.  Wenger also addressed rumors surrounding his players, stating that Hector Bellerin will be offered a contract extension and that Aaron Ramsey will be out for one to two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A man believed to be local and working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday.  Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry into the incident.  The company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

A new charter arrangement will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month, ending a long-running row over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had claimed some workers on board two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour.  Seatruck, who was contracted to run the service by Serco Northlink, argued the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents.  Under the new agreement, all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage.

64-year-old Ken Dickie died on May 14th, six days after an altercation with his girlfriend's son, 35-year-old Jamie Mitchell, at the Rockley Park holiday park in Poole.  Mitchell intervened in an argument between his mother and Mr. Dickie, who were in a relationship at the time.  During the altercation, Mitchell admitted to pushing Mr. Dickie, who fell and hit his head.  Initially, Mitchell and his mother lied to police about the nature of the altercation, but Mitchell later admitted his involvement.  He pled guilty to common assault, and both he and his mother pled guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice. Sentencing is set for February 6th.

Prolific British songwriter Rod Temperton, who wrote Michael Jackson hits Thriller, Rock With You and Off The Wall, has died aged 66 after "a brief aggressive battle with cancer". The Grammy-winning songwriter, who also wrote for artists including Aretha Franklin and Donna Summer, died in London last week, Warner/Chappell music publishing said. Temperton's private funeral has already taken place.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, have discovered 2,000-year-old earthworks in the Brazilian Amazon. These "geoglyphs" are large, geometrical ditches, numbering over 450, that were hidden by rainforest until modern deforestation. The purpose of these geoglyphs is unclear, as they show little evidence of being villages or defensive structures. Researchers hypothesize they were used sporadically, potentially for ritual gatherings. Analysis of soil samples suggests the geoglyphs were constructed amidst tall vegetation, unlike other ritual sites like the Mayan pyramids.  Furthermore, evidence suggests the ancient inhabitants practiced "agroforestry," cultivating economically valuable trees instead of burning large sections of forest. This practice may have contributed to the biodiversity of Acre's remaining forests.

Despite feeling tired and bored, Australian Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, beat American Sam Querrey in the Shanghai Masters tennis tournament. Kyrgios attributed his fatigue to his recent win at the Japan Open and the long commute to the stadium from Shanghai. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, Kyrgios was fined for inappropriate language.

The HPV vaccine is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 in Wales to protect them against cervical cancer. Due to an increase in head and neck cancers in men, charities and organizations are urging the Welsh government to follow suit of other countries and approve the HPV vaccine for boys. They cite data showing the vaccine's effectiveness in reducing HPV-related cancers and emphasize the importance of protecting public health. The Welsh government is awaiting recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old battling gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away from the disease. Diagnosed last August, Trueman documented his journey on the social media page "Jak's Journey." The page garnered over 28,000 likes and showcased his positive attitude, love of the Rangers FC, and time spent with players from the team. Despite his illness, Trueman attended his school prom for a short time, thanking everyone for organizing the event in his honor. He was also awarded the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. After doctors informed Trueman that his cancer had spread, he spent his remaining days with loved ones, attended special events, and helped raise money for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 to keep their hopes of reaching the Africa Cup of Nations quarter-finals alive. Abdallah El Said scored the game's lone goal in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed in the 52nd minute when Joseph Ochaya was ruled offside. Egypt will play Ghana on Wednesday with top spot in Group D at stake, while Uganda will play Mali in their final group game.

Lancashire County Council has selected a site for Skelmersdale's new train station. The chosen location is the former Glenburn Sports College, which was deemed the most suitable location following a comparative study of potential sites. The site was chosen as it allows for future expansion, has good highway access, and good connectivity to the town and surrounding area.  The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land.
Police discovered a sophisticated cannabis growing operation in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. They arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony after being dragged through the streets by her neck. She underwent an emergency operation in a specialist clinic. The woman's 38-year-old ex-partner, who is in custody, turned himself in. Both the victim and suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is unclear.

A study by the Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, looking at 4,600 workers in Australia, found that women are less likely to receive a pay raise than men even though they are just as likely to request one. This debunks the "reticent female" theory that women do not ask for more money.  The study found that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked, when comparing full-time male workers to full-time female workers and part-time male workers with part-time female workers.  Researchers, taking into account employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications, concluded that there was no evidence that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase because they were more wary of upsetting their boss, or deviating from a perceived female stereotype.  However, there was a difference in pay increases when comparing age groups. Men and women under 40 both asked for and received pay rises at the same rate.

Oxford City Council is trying to find land for a new cemetery because existing cemeteries are projected to be full by 2021. Despite conducting ground investigations for many years, no suitable council-owned land has been located due to reasons such as size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants. Once existing cemeteries are full, burial options will be limited to family plots, reserved plots, and interment of ashes.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, is launching an app this year. The app will allow festival attendees to access information and interviews, buy tickets, and view videos and band interviews on their phones.  People around the world can use the app to experience the festival remotely.  Notable acts performing at the festival include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, died after winning the Cotswold Chase.  The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) stated the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage", noting that this is a rare condition that can occur in horses without any underlying health issues.  Many Clouds had previously been treated for overheating and "wobbling" after races, but had not exhibited these symptoms at the Cotswold Chase.  While there were questions about his previous condition being a factor in his death, the BHA concluded the cause was the pulmonary haemorrhage.

Davina, 34, was found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. At the time of the assault, Davina went by the name David Ayrton. The victim stated she had "only drunk a can and a half of Foster's" and clearly remembered the events. Davina will be sentenced on March 4th.  Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, stating she would likely be held at a male prison in Winchester.

Serbian tennis players lost a doubles tennis match to a Brazilian team. This follows a loss the day before by Serbian Novak Djokovic to Argentinian Juan Martin del Potro.  Djokovic, ranked number one in the world, lost in Wimbledon in July and won his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics.

The annual chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Scotland, will feature more than 20 contestants from around the world.  Competitors are only allowed to use chainsaws and will be sculpting animals and people out of logs.  Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will be returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, who has been out since September with a foot injury, is nearing his return. He is aiming to be fit in time for the Six Nations in February.  His first chance to play would be Wales’s opening match against Ireland on February 7th. Webb recently renewed his contract with the Ospreys, his home region, and the Welsh Rugby Union.

US border agents interrupted a smuggling attempt of 26kg of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was apprehended at the scene, while another, Nathan Hall, was later apprehended by Canadian police. Two other individuals, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were arrested for assisting the smuggling by picking up the men and driving the drugs to San Francisco.  All apprehended face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.

Childline reports counseling over 4,500 children for online bullying in the past year, a significant increase from the previous year.  The organization emphasizes the severity of this issue, stating that online trolls cause significant distress and that bullying can have long-lasting impacts on young lives. Childline urges adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and for schools to take the problem seriously. They also highlight the importance of children seeking help when facing bullying.  The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, during which the Anti-Bullying Alliance collaborates with various stakeholders to address this problem.

Following a UN resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has postponed plans for new housing units in East Jerusalem. The postponement comes ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry, who is expected to outline his vision for ending the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The US abstained from the UN vote, which angered Netanyahu, who claims the Obama administration helped draft the resolution.  Netanyahu has responded to the resolution by summoning ambassadors from all 15 Security Council nations, recalling Israeli ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and canceling a visit by Ukraine’s prime minister.  The resolution states that Israeli settlements are “a flagrant violation under international law” and pose a “major obstacle to the achievement of the two-state solution.”  Over 500,000 Jews live in about 140 settlements built since Israel’s 1967 occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem.

Queen Elizabeth II celebrated her 90th birthday. In honor of the Queen's birthday, several events were organized, including a visit to the Royal Mail delivery office, the opening of a new bandstand, and the release of commemorative stamps. Prince William praised the Queen's dedication to her duty and acknowledged the criticisms he has received regarding his own commitment to royal duties. He stated that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is also focused on finding a balance in his life. The Queen's birthday celebrations included the unveiling of a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway and the lighting of a beacon.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0.  West Ham forward Diafra Sakho scored his first goal since November on a pass from Sam Byram.  Moments later, Andre Ayew increased the lead to 2-0.  Cheltenham's best scoring opportunity came on Harry Pell's low volley across goal, but substitute Dan Holman was unable to get the touch needed to score.  The win eliminates Cheltenham Town from EFL Cup competition.

Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, Germany, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving. He struck and killed motorcyclist Aidan McNicholl, 36,  after failing to see him while making a right turn. Werner was fined Â£1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years.  The victim's family stated that they understood the crash was an accident and did not wish the court to impose a jail sentence.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from London, joined the Islamic State affiliate Rayat al Tawheed in Syria and engaged in fighting and recruitment activities. He documented his experience through online videos and pictures, showcasing both the group's propaganda and brutality. After faking his own death, Khawaja attempted to return to the UK but was apprehended by police at Dover. He has pleaded guilty to four offenses, including concealing his entry and faking his death, and is considered a dangerous individual by authorities.

Kayden Jackson, age 22, has signed with Barnsley following his previous season with Wrexham. During his time with Wrexham, Jackson scored four goals in thirty-six appearances.  This will be Barnsley's third signing for the next season.

Numerous bottles of Vanish laundry detergent have washed up on Cornish beaches, suspected to be from a container that fell overboard from the MV Blue Ocean near Land's End in May. While unconfirmed if the bottles are from the ship, the National Trust is clearing the bottles due to potential risks to wildlife. The public is advised to avoid contact with the bottles.
A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 2:00 PM.  The crash resulted in several injuries and a road closure.  An investigation into the incident is ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28 year-old French center-back, signed a contract to stay with Bolton Wanderers following their promotion to the Championship. Though he only made 14 appearances last season, manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contributions to the team's second-place finish in League One.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour are experiencing a breakdown in relations over Brexit amendments. Although the parties previously collaborated to defeat the government on issues like EU citizen rights and Brexit deal approval, their cooperation dissolved when the Commons rejected their amendments. The Lib Dems, determined to uphold these amendments, accused Labour of "conceding everything" by aligning with the Conservatives and supporting a hard Brexit. Labour, however, criticized the Lib Dems for offering "false hope" and engaging in "grandstanding" for campaign purposes. Despite this rift, both parties expressed a willingness to collaborate on future issues, though Labour acknowledged lingering tensions.

This election issue discusses foreign policy and the role of the UK’s defense forces at home and abroad. With the world becoming more unstable and dangerous, the UK has been making significant cuts to its armed forces alongside other European nations. Although the UK is the fourth biggest spender on defense in the world, it is projected to fall below the NATO threshold of 2% by the end of the decade.  While the Conservative Party is committed to increasing the defense equipment budget by 1% a year, other parties such as Labour and the Liberal Democrats have avoided making similar commitments. All of this leads to uncertainty surrounding the UK’s defense policy.

Barcelona FC has made an additional tax payment of  €13,550,830.56 in relation to Neymar's transfer to the club.  Although the club insists they met their tax obligations when they paid €57 million for the striker in 2013, a Spanish judge ruled that there was enough evidence to investigate the transfer.  The club states this recent payment is to cover any possible discrepancies in the interpretation of the contracts and to protect the reputation of the club.

Michael Luciw, 27, died in a car crash when a car driving the wrong way on the motorway, driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, hit the van in which Luciw was a passenger.  Luciw's family believes older drivers should have more frequent driving tests, while Age UK believes drivers should be able to drive as long as it is safe.  Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK self-assess their ability to drive every three years when they renew their licenses.

An independent review of transvaginal mesh implants, which are used to treat incontinence, has been conducted in Scotland. The review concluded that the procedure should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended that patients be offered a range of treatments and given information to make informed choices. The review also said reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. The review was controversial, with two patients quitting the review group in protest and the chairwoman apologizing for failing to unite all panel members around the final report.  Over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, but some have suffered painful and debilitating complications. More than 400 women are currently taking legal action against Scottish health boards and manufacturers as a result of mesh implant surgery.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish runner, broke Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old 5,000-meter record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. Though McColgan initially expressed concerns about the race’s validity as a record-breaking attempt because Muir was the only competitor to run the full 5,000 meters, British Athletics confirmed Muir’s time is expected to be officially ratified as a new British record. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to run even faster and “mix it with the top in the world.”

Michael Jung won the gold medal in equestrian riding Sam, after the original rider, Fischertakinou, was unable to compete.  Astier Nicolas of France took the silver medal, and Phillip Dutton from America won the bronze.  William Fox-Pitt of Great Britain finished twelfth after a disappointing cross-country round, despite a strong showing in the final show-jumping phase.  Jonty Evans of Ireland, riding Cooley Rorkes Drift, finished in ninth place.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 to advance to the round of 16 at Wimbledon.  After dropping the second set, Murray rallied to take the third.  In a back and forth fourth set that saw Murray overcome a 2-5 deficit, Murray ultimately prevailed, winning the final five games of the match.  Murray will face Benoit Paire in the next round.

Colleen O'Neill, the license holder of Joe's Bar in Dungiven, and employee James Thomas, were charged with selling alcohol outside of legal licensing hours. Police were called to the bar at 06:00 BST on October 6, 2014, for a sudden death and discovered patrons still drinking in the establishment. Till receipts indicated alcohol sales as late as 04:49 BST.  The judge presiding over the case, citing Ms. O'Neill's "appalling record," ordered the bar closed for three months. Ms. O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000.

The central message of Ulster Unionist Party Leader Mike Nesbitt’s speech, and the party’s manifesto, entitled “Real Partnership”, was a call for action to address issues such as hospital waiting lists, increasing police officer numbers, and standing up for the LGBTQIA community. The party is hoping these initiatives will resonate with voters more than the controversy over Nesbitt’s remarks about transferring votes to the SDLP.

Northern Ireland's Justice Minister Claire Sugden has announced a motion to pardon men convicted under abolished sexual offense laws.  The motion will bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales' "Turing's Law," which automatically pardons deceased men convicted under these laws and allows living men convicted under these laws to apply for pardons.  The motion will require assembly approval.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old runner from Kinross, achieved a new Scottish record in the 1500m race. She finished second behind Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4 minutes and 19.12 seconds, surpassing Yvonne Murray's previous record of 4:22.60 set in 1994. This accomplishment places Muir second on the British all-time list.  Muir's achievement was praised by Murray through her husband, Tom Mooney, via Facebook.  Muir will participate in the British trials in Birmingham from June 24th to 26th in pursuit of qualifying for the Olympics in Rio.
This document describes a collection of pictures. The pictures are from the 26 beaches in Scotland that have the best water quality.

Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian agent who accused the Russian state of corruption and political assassinations, was poisoned with polonium-210 in 2006 and later died.  Although it is believed that the Russian state sponsored the poisoning, the motives are unknown. The two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, have denied any involvement and remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, age 26, has been appointed captain of the Australian Test cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke, who retired after the team lost the Ashes to England.  Smith previously captained the team in three matches against India when Clarke was injured.  David Warner, age 28, will be Smith's vice-captain.  The appointments were made by Rod Marsh, the national selector, who said Smith has the skills and temperament to be a successful captain.  Warner has matured and developed into an important senior player for Australia, according to Marsh. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches that follow the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron, leader of the Liberal Democrats, stated that protecting the rights of the LGBTQ+ community would be a priority under his leadership. He supports equal marriage and wants to extend marital rights to transgender people, who currently face a spousal veto when one partner undergoes a gender change. While Farron maintains that he is a liberal and supports equality, he did not directly answer questions about his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, which would have provided more protections for gay people against discrimination. He explained that he voted against the bill due to concerns about “protection of individual liberties” after a Lib Dem amendment addressing these concerns was defeated.

Accord Healthcare is reopening a pharmaceutical plant in Fawdon that was closed in 2015.  The plant is expected to bring back many of the 450 jobs that were lost when the previous company closed the site.  Accord Healthcare distributes pharmaceuticals to about 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their positions at the local council. Ellis's contract is ending, while Monaghan and Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme.  Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, believes more departures will follow.

English rider Guy Martin has withdrawn from the Ulster Grand Prix following mechanical problems with his Honda Fireblade bike at the Isle of Man TT. Martin insists that he is not quitting road racing altogether but will not race his Honda in any more road races this year. He cited his disappointment with the bike's performance and his role as a test rider as reasons for his withdrawal. Martin expressed his desire to participate in classic and unique races in the future.

In Nigeria's elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) secured victory in 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking a significant setback for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. This follows the APC's presidential win the previous month. The PDP's losses were particularly notable in key northern states. However, the PDP retained control of Rivers State, a crucial oil-producing region. Notably, the APC did not secure victory in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, posing a potential challenge to President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections, while marred by some violence, were deemed more peaceful compared to previous years, suggesting a maturing democracy in Nigeria. The PDP, having been in power for 16 years, faced allegations of corruption and criticism for its handling of the Islamist-led insurgency in the north-east.

A US environmental group, Mighty, has accused Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, Olam, of using unsustainable palm oil trading practices. Mighty claims that Olam sources palm oil from suppliers that engage in environmentally damaging practices, such as deforestation and burning, which contribute to the annual haze affecting Southeast Asia. Olam, a newcomer to the palm oil industry, denies these allegations, stating that they have a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and are committed to sustainable sourcing. However, Olam only recently disclosed the names of its 14 suppliers after pressure from Mighty.  Mighty also implicates Olam's main stakeholder, Singapore's state-owned investment company Temasek, suggesting their investment unknowingly supports unsustainable practices. Temasek refutes these claims, stating they support no-burn policies and do not interfere in the operations of their portfolio companies. The palm oil industry faces criticism for its environmental and social impact, with activists urging governments to hold non-compliant companies accountable. However, changing government policies proves challenging as these companies often provide jobs and investment. Mighty also raises concerns about Olam's operations in Gabon, Africa, where they allege similar unsustainable practices are being employed. Olam maintains that their partnerships in Gabon
A restaurant began serving "puppy platters" outdoors after a new law allowed dogs to dine at restaurants if they remained outside.
Fernando Forestieri (knee) may not play due to his injury. David Nugent (groin) might return after missing a game, and Jacob Butterfield (midfielder) hopes to be recalled.

Pakistan banned YouTube in 2012 after the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded to the platform.  The ban was recently lifted after Google, which owns YouTube, launched a Pakistan-specific version.  The Pakistani government states that they will be able to request the blocking of offensive content, but YouTube maintains that any removal requests will be subject to review and are not automatically granted.

FIFA presidential candidate Musa Bility is demanding that Domenico Scala, head of FIFA’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, excuse himself from the upcoming election because he shares a nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility cites a conflict of interest, pointing to the 2015 election where Scala excused himself for the same reason. However, Scala claims that the situation is different because, in 2015, the shared nationality was with the incumbent president.  Bility has threatened to take his demand to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion while working at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday. The incident occurred in a paint-spraying area around 09:00 BST.  A forensic investigation suggests that a buildup of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source caused a fireball effect.

Tunisia and Morocco were both facing bans from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations but will now be allowed to compete after disputes with the Confederation of African Football (Caf) were resolved. Morocco were initially banned after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to fears over the Ebola virus but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced their fine. Tunisia were facing expulsion after writing a letter of complaint to Caf following their controversial quarter-final defeat to Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament. The Tunisian Football Federation, however, insisted that it never accused Caf or the match referee of corruption and the matter has now been resolved.  After both teams were cleared to compete in the 2017 qualifying rounds, the draw placed Tunisia in Group A alongside Togo, Liberia and Djibouti while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome in Group F.

Following a large fight at the end of a match between Manchester City and Chelsea, two Manchester City players, Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho, received bans. Aguero was banned for four matches, while Fernandinho was banned for three.

Wales has some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. To combat this, a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath Port Talbot will focus on patients whose GPs suspect cancer but lack clear symptoms. This comes after a visit to Denmark revealed their successful diagnostic system. The concern is that Welsh patients without clear symptoms wait too long for diagnosis because they don't fit specific treatment paths. This leads to multiple referrals and tests, taking weeks. Consequently, many begin treatment when their cancer is advanced or incurable. The pilot will allow 40 Cwm Cynon GPs to refer patients to a diagnostic center within seven days. Six patients will be seen weekly, undergoing various tests on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with "worrying" symptoms in Cwm Taf are diagnosed. Doctors aim to reach those without obvious symptoms sooner. A similar clinic will be established in Neath Port Talbot Hospital. These trials follow a 12-month period after experts visited Aarhus, Denmark, which established diagnostic centers to improve its own cancer survival rates. Dr. Gareth Davies believes this will ease patient anxiety and speed up the process. The pilot will allow GPs to directly refer patients for quick assessment and diagnosis. Dr.

England beat Pakistan by 330 runs in the second Test at Old Trafford to level the four-match series at 1-1. Joe Root, who was promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second.  Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq commented on his team's performance stating they are short of confidence and that shot selection cost them. The third Test at Edgbaston gets underway on 3 August.

Warren Gatland, head coach for the British and Irish Lions, has appointed Rob Howley as interim coach.  Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales during the Lions' tour.  The WRU will announce assistant coaches next week.  Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the experience Welsh coaches gain from the Lions' tour will benefit the national team.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1.  Southampton started strong after a clumsy challenge by Curtis Davies on Maya Yoshida led to a successful penalty kick by Charlie Austin in the 6th minute.  However, the entrance of Robert Snodgrass onto the field in the 26th minute invigorated a lackluster Hull team.  Snodgrass scored a goal and had an assist within the first 10 minutes of the second half, leading his team to victory.  Despite a late surge by Southampton, Hull goalkeeper David Marshall made a string of saves to secure the win for his team.

A motorcyclist died after a crash with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at approximately 14:15 BST. The tractor driver was unharmed. Police are asking anyone who witnessed the crash to contact them.

Macedonia's President Ivanov canceled an investigation stemming from covert recordings that allegedly exposed government corruption. Ivanov stated his intention was to quell unrest ahead of an election, but the decision was denounced by both EU officials and Macedonian opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who accused Ivanov of acting illegally. Zaev, who released the recordings, claims they reveal government corruption, while officials deny any wrongdoing.

Swansea City are looking to appoint a new manager after Bob Bradley was sacked.  Their first choice is the ex-Derby manager Paul Clement.  Curtis, a former player and current caretaker manager, feels Swansea have lost their way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, especially with the high turnover in managerial positions since.  He believes the current squad is good enough to stay up, but acknowledges the increasing difficulty for newly relegated clubs to make it back to the Premier League.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient.  Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona giving them hope, Armand Gnanduillet scored the game winner for Orient. Dagenham manager John Still, who returned to the club in December, stated he is committed to helping the club gain promotion from the National League next season.  Leyton Orient interim manager Andy Hessenthaler, who took over after the recent firing of player-manager Kevin Nolan, expressed relief at the win while acknowledging the team's need to improve.

Steven Gerrard, former Liverpool captain, will be returning to his old club as a youth coach. Gerrard, who retired in November after a 19-year career, says he hopes to become a manager one day. He will begin working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League.

Morton obtained a comfortable win over Alloa.  McManus scored first, followed by a goal from Forbes. Alloa's McAusland scored before the half.  McManus scored again, and Johnstone added a final goal to secure the win.

Ofsted investigations have uncovered illegal schools operating in appalling conditions, primarily within Muslim communities in the Midlands.  Three such schools in Birmingham have been shut down, with proprietors facing potential legal action.  Although operating under the guise of part-time educational centers or "flexi schools," these institutions exploit legal loopholes surrounding home education.  Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expresses concern over potential abuse and radicalization within these unregulated settings.  The government has allocated resources for investigating and prosecuting those operating illegal schools, emphasizing that this action will be applicable across all religious groups.

The Scottish Borders will soon be home to its first new gin distillery in nearly two centuries. Lilliard Gin, named after a local legend, will be produced at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh.  The distillery will utilize a small-batch production process and locally sourced botanicals to create a gin that reflects the unique flavors of the region.

Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal alcohol limit, fatally struck Harry Whitlam with a tractor at Swithens Farm in August 2013. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. Although the incident occurred on private land, the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) found Green's actions reckless and charged him under health and safety legislation.  Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed the profound impact of the loss on her family and emphasized the importance of responsible alcohol consumption, regardless of location.

Luis Suarez, a player for Barcelona, was banned by FIFA from all football-related activities for biting Italian player Giorgio Chiellini. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) ruled that the ban on Suarez participating in football-related activities was excessive, though the ban on playing in organized matches was upheld.  Suarez is now allowed to train and play in friendly matches, but will still be required to serve the remainder of his nine-match ban in competitive games.  CAS will publish a full explanation of the ruling at a later date.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race in which male contestants must carry a female teammate through an obstacle course. They beat the Lithuanian team, who were their toughest competition. The course is 380 meters and includes obstacles such as haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols.  Blake-Smith and his partner trained for a week by running on a track. They will move on to compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government's decision to eliminate the paper car tax disc and transition to an electronic system will likely result in job role changes and potential reductions in staff numbers at the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) in Swansea. However, the government is committed to retraining and redeploying employees within the organization rather than resorting to redundancies.

Hungary's right-wing government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is facing pressure from the EU to withdraw three laws: one concerning asylum seekers, another on NGOs, and a higher education law.  The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, in addition to a higher education law that critics say could lead to the closure of the Central European University.  Hungary's Foreign Minister said the EU should not interfere with "domestic issues" and that Poland would veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights.

"Beauty and the Beast" will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson will star as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston.  Rounding out the cast is Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts.  Bill Condon will direct the film.

Adrian Gill, a controversial and celebrated journalist known for his sharp wit and fearless writing, has died at the age of 62. Gill, who had been battling "the full English" of cancers, passed away on Saturday, leaving behind a legacy of provocative commentary and unparalleled prose.  Gill's career, spanning three decades, saw him rise to prominence as a giant in the industry, captivating readers with his unique style and often controversial viewpoints. He will be remembered for his contributions to The Sunday Times, where he served as the heart and soul of the paper, consistently delivering dazzling and thought-provoking columns. Beyond his professional achievements, Gill was a cherished friend and colleague, whose loss has left a void in the lives of those who knew him.

Mongolian rapper, Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, was allegedly attacked while performing in Ulan Bator. The suspect, an unidentified Russian diplomat, allegedly assaulted Sukhbaatar, resulting in a 10-day coma and serious brain injury, according to the rapper's father. The alleged attack stemmed from Sukhbaatar wearing a deel embroidered with a swastika, a symbol that holds traditional significance in Mongolia but is associated with Nazism in Russia. While the Russian embassy in Mongolia disputes details circulating in the media, Sukhbaatar's lawyer maintains the suspect should be held accountable under Mongolian law.

Plane Stupid, an activist group, held a demonstration against airport expansion plans on Monday at 3:30 BST.  The protesters were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. Their court date is August 19th.  Airport security will be reviewed as a result.

Nick Selman's century (101 off 144 balls) was the backbone of Glamorgan's total of 220, an innings in which Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took wickets regularly.  Selman's knock was a return to form after a string of low scores, and helped Glamorgan recover from a poor start. Gloucestershire faced a tough evening session, with the bowlers on top all day.  At stumps, Gloucestershire were still batting, with the match evenly balanced.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old from Flint, was arrested in August for threatening to lure police to the Dee Estuary with a false report and then shoot them.  Hughes made the threats against police on two separate occasions during late-night conversations with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee.  He was out on bail for firearms offenses, of which he was later cleared, at the time of the threats. Hughes will be sentenced next week.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire in a Royal London One-Day Cup match. Despite a strong start by Yorkshire, a century by Davies and 90 by Foakes propelled Surrey to a total of 255.  Meaker took three crucial wickets for Surrey, including those of Bairstow and Ballance. Yorkshire's run chase faltered, and they were eventually bowled out for 236, with Bresnan top-scoring with 68.  Surrey won by 19 runs.

A 56ft trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, reported flooding at 07:00 BST. The onboard pump was overwhelmed, prompting the crew to radio for assistance.  The RNLI lifeboat crew deployed an additional pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games in April due to veterinary medicine exams. Despite this, she is happy with her performance at the World Athletics Championships, where she achieved a new personal best in the 5,000m. She is aiming to compete in the World Indoor Championships in March and is confident about her future in running, believing she has at least two more Olympics in her.

This article by Robbie Savage analyzes the reasons why Liverpool are struggling in the current season. Savage argues that last season's success was an overachievement and that the team is now experiencing a decline due to several factors. Firstly, the departure of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injury have significantly impacted Liverpool's goal-scoring ability, as the replacements haven't been able to fill the void. Secondly, the defense remains a weakness despite significant investment, with no clear leader emerging. Lastly, while Gerrard remains a key player, his age is becoming a factor, and the team needs to find ways to compensate for his declining physical abilities. Savage predicts a challenging match against Chelsea, who are currently performing at a much higher level. Despite the criticisms, Savage believes Gerrard still has a future at Liverpool, particularly in a defensive midfield role, and his experience and leadership remain valuable assets.

A new £45 million educational campus will be built in Kilmarnock, Scotland, and named after the late author William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in the town. The campus will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. McIlvanney, who passed away on December 5th, was known for his gritty, realistic novels set in Glasgow, earning him the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He was also an English teacher, poet, journalist, and broadcaster.

A British sea mine, dating back to the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered in the river near Gourock. As a precaution, an exclusion zone was set up encompassing the immediate vicinity of the river and a 500m radius, affecting three streets. Residents within this radius were advised to stay indoors, while those in the evacuated zone were unable to return to their homes for much of the day.  Ferry services were also disrupted.  The Royal Navy’s Northern Diving Unit, led by Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis, decided to move the mine due to its deteriorated state before safely disposing of it.   Inverclyde Council expressed gratitude for the patience and cooperation of residents during the evacuation.

Team GB will invest £345 million, slightly less than it invested for the Rio Games, across 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports to fund 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals at the 2020 Tokyo Games. While some sports, such as judo, saw an increase in funding, others, such as cycling, saw a decrease, and others, such as badminton, had their funding removed entirely. UK Sport, the organization distributing the funds, claims to prioritize “protect[ing] and enhance[ing] medal potential,” which is why some sports received funding and others did not.  However, some athletes and coaches are frustrated with this decision, especially athletes participating in sports added to the 2020 Games, such as baseball.  They claim that without funding, they will be unable to train to the best of their ability and will therefore be unable to earn medals.

Despite objections from English Heritage and some residents, Bournemouth Council approved the demolition of three Victorian hotels in a conservation area.  The plan replaces the hotels with a six-storey hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks.  While acknowledging the loss of the buildings, the council stated that the project would boost tourism and provide housing for older residents.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier, was killed in an attack outside a Brecon bar on May 8th. Jake Vallely, 24, punched and beat Pte Boyd before dragging his body away from the scene. Vallely will be sentenced on December 8th.  Aaeron Evans, a friend of Vallely's, was cleared of manslaughter after it was determined he was not present during the attack.  Pte Boyd's family described him as a loving person with a promising career ahead of him, and they expressed gratitude for the outpouring of support from the Brecon community.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, has left his position by "mutual agreement" after an error that resulted in voters being turned away from polling stations because their names were not on the list. An independent investigation has been launched to review the incident and the council has apologized, offering emergency proxy votes to affected residents.  The review will conclude by the end of May and will be presented to the General Functions Committee.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored first for Gateshead with a free kick. Sean Newton tied the game with a free kick before halftime. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead, heading in a cross from Craig Baxter.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluated the social and economic well-being of individuals aged 60 and above in 96 countries. Norway ranked first, while Afghanistan held the lowest position, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb and Airbus are partnering to create a network of satellites that will provide broadband internet access to every corner of the globe. The project will require the launch of over 2,000 satellites, which will be built using new, high-volume, low-cost assembly line methods. The first satellites are scheduled to launch in April 2020, with the goal of having the full constellation operational by the middle of the decade. OneWeb and Airbus are not the only companies planning to launch large constellations of satellites, but they believe they have a first-mover advantage. The project has already raised $1.7 billion in equity, and talks are ongoing to secure the loans needed to complete the rollout. The UK Space Agency is responsible for licensing the project, and it is sure to take a keen interest in debris mitigation. OneWeb has committed to de-orbiting its old satellites within two years to reduce the risk of collisions. Time will tell how disruptive the new manufacturing approaches adopted by OneWeb and Airbus will be to the satellite industry as a whole.

The Scottish government will have £390 million more in spending available to them next year, which rises to £750 million if you include its own underspend. The UK government said that this means the block grant will be almost £30 billion. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010, along with last month's spending review, mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11.

For many people with severe disabilities, being unable to access Changing Places toilets, which are larger than standard accessible toilets and include features such as hoists and changing benches,  severely restricts their enjoyment of everyday activities. Although recommendations are in place to support installing Changing Places toilets in larger buildings, campaigners are calling for these recommendations to be made compulsory.  They highlight the distress and indignity caused to individuals and families, emphasizing the need for greater consideration and inclusivity in building design. While some businesses face logistical and financial challenges in incorporating these facilities, the positive impact on accessibility and social inclusion is undeniable, as demonstrated by the success of Changing Places installations in venues like Arsenal Football Club.

Italian consumer groups have filed a complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald's of abusing its market dominance by charging excessive rents and fees to franchisees.  The groups allege that these practices result in reduced consumer choice and inflated prices at franchised locations compared to company-owned stores.  They also claim that McDonald's compels franchisees to sign lengthy contracts, hindering their ability to switch to competitors.  The European Commission is reviewing the complaint and may initiate an investigation.  McDonald's maintains that its franchise model, based on shared risks and rewards, has been successful and beneficial for both franchisees and consumers.

Thirteen-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. What started as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on staff, has gone viral with people all over the world showing their support.  A mystery donor even paid for a billboard with the hashtag #prayforjosh to be erected at Holywood playing fields.

The UK Ministry of Defence plans to close Brecon Barracks, a fixture in the town since 1805.  Brecon and Radnorshire MP Chris Davies condemned the decision, citing the Barracks' rich history and the impact its closure would have on the area, including job losses and damage to the tourism industry.  Davies plans to fight the decision.  The Defence Secretary stated that the closure is part of a larger restructuring plan that will create a specialist light infantry center at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan.

While the UK fishing industry feels positive about the outcome of Brexit in regaining control of fishing waters, the House of Lords released a report highlighting risks. The report states that as the UK fishing industry makes up such a small percentage of the GDP, it may not be a priority in negotiations. Continued access to EU markets will be essential for the UK fishing industry to thrive after Brexit, but that may come at the price of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. The report also advises the UK to maintain elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), such as basing catch limits on scientific advice.  In response to the report, the government states that it will prioritize the UK’s ability to trade with the single market, but also sees Brexit as an opportunity to make changes to the fishing industry.

Leaked documents revealed that the NSA has access to personal data from major technology companies like Google and Facebook. The program, called Prism, was justified by the US government as a tool to prevent terrorism. While government officials maintain that law-abiding citizens are not affected, privacy advocates are concerned about the scope of the program and the lack of transparency and control for users whose data is stored in the US.

OpenAI is a new research venture that seeks to advance digital intelligence to benefit humanity.  Headed by Elon Musk and other tech giants, the venture aims to develop AI free from financial obligations.  While some experts like Musk and Stephen Hawking warn about the potential threat of AI to humanity, OpenAI believes that AI used correctly could greatly benefit society.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was injured by a bomb in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th.  As a result, he received thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the maximum limit of 5,000.  Despite losing his speech following the injury, L/Bdr Parkinson is described as humorous and intelligent.  He spends his time exercising, raising money for charities, and inspiring others.  His mother, Diane, has been overwhelmed by the outpouring of support, noting the increase in mail, email, and website traffic.  Facebook suggests that L/Bdr Parkinson create a public page to accommodate the volume of requests.

In 2011, 46.2 million Americans were in poverty, reflecting a stagnant poverty rate of 15% following three years of increases. Despite the plateauing poverty rate, real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%.  Positively, the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%.  This data comes after a record high poverty rate of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, has signed a deal to remain with Lancashire until 2019. Buttler is considered one of the most talented cricketers, holding England's three fastest ODI centuries.  His presence was cited as a contributing factor to Lancashire winning last year's T20 Blast final.  Buttler will return to Lancashire from the Indian Premier League on Friday to play in the T20 Blast home game.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates are moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting their fate.  While no preservation proposals were submitted, bids for the ships are being finalized, with at least one ship to be awarded to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity.  A final decision on the ships' futures will be made in the spring.  Options include scrapping, reefing, and diving attractions, with a focus on maximizing financial return for the taxpayer.

Fiji has experienced a history of political unrest and racial tensions since 1987, mainly stemming from coups led by indigenous Fijians against the Indo-Fijian population. This turmoil has negatively impacted Fiji's economy, particularly tourism, and its international standing. Coups in 1987 and 2000 led to the establishment and subsequent withdrawal of a constitution favoring indigenous Fijian rule and the hostage situation of the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister.  Another coup in 2006 resulted in Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth until democratic elections were held in 2014. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians, who constitute a slight majority, and Indo-Fijians, with minimal intergroup mixing and prevalent societal segregation. The economy, reliant on sugar, tourism, mining, and services, faces challenges such as trade deficits and a dependence on foreign aid.

Syria missed their Wednesday deadline to hand over its chemical weapons stockpile, claiming a shipment of weapons was intercepted by terrorist fire on its way to Latakia. Although the US expressed concern over the delay, Syria insists they are committed to fulfilling the obligations agreed upon with the OPCW and UN Security Council.  Additionally, Syria denies allegations of government forces using barrel bombs on civilians in Aleppo, stating they are defending their people against terrorist attacks. However, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims rebels have seized control of Aleppo's central prison, which reportedly holds at least 3,000 detainees.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist includes the following authors and novels: *Neel Mukherjee for "The Lives of Others"* *Ali Smith for "How To Be Both"* *Joshua Ferris for "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour"* *Karen Joy Fowler for "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves"* *Richard Flanagan for "The Narrow Road to the Deep North"* *Howard Jacobson for "J"*

The winner will be announced on Tuesday night at London's Guildhall.  The award will be presented by The Duchess of Cornwall.

A well-known man, referred to as PJS, is appealing to the Supreme Court after an appeal court lifted a ban that protected his identity from being published by the media in England and Wales. PJS, who has a spouse and children who are also in the public eye, had previously won an appeal that prevented the Sun on Sunday from publishing a story about his alleged extramarital affair that began in 2009. However, due to the story being published in other countries and on the internet, the courts ruled that PJS would likely be unable to obtain a permanent injunction because confidentiality had “probably been lost.”

Fosse Park, purchased in August for Â£345.5m, will be undergoing improvements to address parking, traffic congestion, and the overall appearance of the shopping park.  The new owners, Crown Estates, plan to invest in enhancing the "common areas" including walkways and parking areas, to improve the customer experience.

Malaysia's Censorship Board has approved the release of the Beauty and the Beast remake after requiring a minor edit concerning a gay moment in the film. Homosexuality is illegal in the Muslim-majority country. The film was given a P13 parental guidance classification.  Local cinema chains are offering refunds for advance ticket purchases as a new release date has not been announced.

Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in the area.  Landlords renting properties to more than three unrelated people need to apply for this license, which can cost ??1,000. Failure to obtain the proper licensing could result in a fine of up to ??20,000.  Southampton City Council stated that a small number of landlords have resisted applying for the HMO license, resulting in prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.  Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan receives five to six calls daily from tenants concerned about fear of eviction and poorly maintained HMO properties. Nationally, mandatory licensing for HMOs is aimed at houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people.  In Southampton, the licenses affect properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1 - introduced in 2013) and in Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2 - introduced in 2015).

The main Irish political parties, Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil, are attempting to form a government and avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil has agreed to facilitate a minority government led by Fine Gael but will not support a program for government.  Disagreement over water charges is a significant obstacle to the parties reaching an agreement.

The Italian ferry, The Sorrento, caught fire and was evacuated off the coast of Mallorca. The fire began on a car deck and the cause is unknown.  Three passengers were injured and taken to a hospital, one seriously. All other passengers and crew are safe after being evacuated to a ferry that is returning them to Palma de Mallorca. The Sorrento may sink.

Concerns remain over duplicate voter registrations in the UK's 8 June 2017 election despite a record number of voters (46.8 million) registering.  The Electoral Commission reported that 2.9 million applications were received during the 6-week registration period, but the net increase in voters was only 1.4 million.  Because there is no way to check if someone is already registered to vote when they register online, duplicate applications are estimated to be between 30-70%.  While it is lawful to be registered in more than one constituency, it is a criminal offense, punishable by an unlimited fine, to vote twice in a general election.  The Electoral Commission recommends a cross-check system be implemented to reduce duplicate voter registrations.

At a ceremony in Chester celebrating eight years of the Mercian Regiment, Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, was promoted to lance corporal.  He received this honor from Brigadier Andrew Williams, the colonel of the regiment, for his "good behavior".  Lance Corporal Derby XXX is the 30th mascot ram for the regiment, a tradition dating back to the mid-19th century.  He officially joined the regiment in 2014 and even has his own army number and salary.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a thrilling game characterized by a dramatic Liverpool comeback. Down 2-0 early after a dazzling offensive showcase from Dortmund, Liverpool scored three unanswered goals to take the lead before Dortmund tied the game 3-3. In injury time, a late goal from Dejan Lovren secured the victory for Liverpool. The win embodied the fighting spirit instilled in the team by manager Jurgen Klopp, who urged his team to continue believing in themselves even when trailing by multiple goals. The victory, while showcasing Liverpool's offensive firepower and resilience, also highlighted defensive vulnerabilities that will need to be addressed in the future.  The win evokes Liverpool's improbable 2005 Champions League victory and may be a sign of more success to come under Klopp.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis announced a plan to share Brexit negotiation analysis with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland on a monthly basis.  Scottish Brexit Minister Michael Russell agreed that this was a good first step but insisted that the UK government needed to be more transparent about its goals for Brexit negotiations, specifically regarding whether it would seek to remain inside the single market and the customs union.

Thirteen cloned sheep, including four (Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy) that are genetic duplicates of Dolly the sheep, are being studied at the University of Nottingham to determine if cloned animals age normally.  This research is considered critical to the future of cloning because Dolly the sheep died at age six and a half from a virus and osteoarthritis.  Scientists are specifically looking for signs of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis in the cloned sheep through regular joint x-rays, full-body fMRI scans, and physical examinations.  The results of the study are expected to be released soon.

Shutter Speed, the favorite to win, won the Musidora Stakes for trainer John Gosden and jockey Frankie Dettori.  Shutter Speed will be raced in the French Oaks instead of the Epsom Oaks.  Stablemates Enable and Coronet will race in the Epsom Oaks.  Gosden may choose to not race Cracksman in the Dante Stakes due to concerns over the ground.

The value of the pound sterling experienced significant volatility due to polls indicating a higher likelihood of the UK voting to leave the European Union.  Investors, concerned about the economic impact of a potential Brexit, reacted strongly, causing drops in the pound's value against other major currencies and impacting stock markets globally. Despite this, Leave campaigners maintain that a weaker pound would benefit UK exporters, citing recent figures showing a narrowing trade deficit driven by increased exports.

Braintree Town, a part-time team, lost to Barrow, who are on a nine-game unbeaten run, after a goal in the first five minutes.  Despite the loss, which is their third in a row, manager Cowley remains positive, calling their achievements so far "remarkable" given that they are still in sixth place, just outside the playoffs.

Starting in April 2015, local councils in Northern Ireland will be responsible for making decisions on planning applications in their areas. Currently, this power rests with the Planning Service. Proponents, like Michael Corr of PLACE, believe that this change will give local councils the opportunity to implement their own community and development plans. However, others, like James Orr of Friends of the Earth, are concerned that this shift in power could lead to discrimination and unfairness, similar to what occurred in the 1960s with the allocation of public housing.  There are also concerns about the close relationships between developers and political parties and the lack of transparency surrounding political donations.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie, belonging to Sarah Nisbett, was shot three times by an air gun in NiddryView, Winchburgh. The cat survived but had to have a leg amputated. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information to contact them. They are also using this incident to advocate for the licensing of air guns, a measure that was rejected by 87% of respondents when the Scottish government proposed it last year.

Liverpool has signed Belgium international Christian Benteke for a club-record fee. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 appearances for Aston Villa, is Liverpool's seventh signing of the summer. Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has been eager to bolster his attacking options after a disappointing 2014-15 season in which the Reds only finished sixth in the Premier League.

Tablet usage in schools is increasing, and while they are viewed favorably by students and educators, there is no conclusive evidence that they improve academic performance.  Tablets are believed to increase student motivation and family engagement, and are viewed as a necessary part of a 21st century education. While no causal link can be made between tablets and academic improvement, educators in the study reported a positive impact from tablet use.

The exhibition, Growing Up in the City, at the Museum of Liverpool, features 25 photographs depicting the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. The photographs illustrate how childhood has evolved over the century and how special occasions were celebrated. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History at the Museum of Liverpool, also highlights the differences in children's lives, with some depicted as playing while others worked.  The exhibition runs until September 25th.

Torquay United have signed center-back Myles Anderson, 27,  and striker Ruairi Keating, 21. Anderson joins from National League rivals Barrow, while Keating joins from Finn Harps.  Torquay, currently four points above relegation, hope the pair will bolster their chances of survival.

Bolivia passed a law that lowers the minimum working age to 12 with parental permission. The Vice President, Alvaro Garcia Linera, stated that while this seems at odds with international law, the economic realities of the country, one of the poorest in South America, necessitate the change.  The law, which also increases penalties for crimes against children, is facing scrutiny by the International Labour Organisation to determine if it violates international child labor regulations.

After experiencing symptoms such as chest pain, nausea, and fever, actress Rosie O'Donnell searched online for "women's heart attack symptoms."  She then took aspirin and saw a cardiologist the following day, who discovered a 99 percent blockage in one of her arteries.  O'Donnell had suffered a "widow maker" heart attack.  She cautioned women to recognize the symptoms of a heart attack and to call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a 17-year-old from Harrow, was fatally stabbed at a party in Kenton on Saturday evening.  Although the party was well-run, a group of youths who were denied entry were involved in an altercation that later resulted in the stabbing of Che in a nearby alleyway.  A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder, as well as two boys, aged 15 and 16.  A 14-year-old was also arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark noticed their cancer survival rates were lagging behind other European countries due to long wait times for diagnosis, especially for cases that were not initially obvious. To combat this, they created a three-pronged approach: fast-tracking patients with obvious cancer symptoms, establishing diagnostic centers for patients with vague symptoms to receive a range of tests quickly, and creating "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms unlikely to be cancer, allowing for quick identification of the rare serious case. This system has led to better organization and, importantly, better survival rates, demonstrating how improved organization can lead to better patient outcomes.

Powys Council will take over responsibility from the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in overseeing estate agent activities in the UK. The council will handle cases referred by local trading standards departments, issuing warnings and bans to agents who violate the Estate Agents Act. This new responsibility will provide Powys council with £170,000 per year.

The Nuffield Trust, commissioned by NHS Employers, explored how to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce to address staff shortages.  The review found nurses already filling in for doctors and pharmacists, and highlighted areas experimenting with expanded staff roles. While this could help with doctor shortages and address the changing nature of care, the Nuffield Trust acknowledged funding would be needed.  Unions cautioned against viewing this as a quick fix, emphasizing the importance of doctor training and the need for funding to support training courses for expanded staff roles.

A road closure on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath, due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays for commuters and bus services. The road reopened at 14:00 GMT, and bus services are expected to be back to a normal schedule by the evening commute.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that a proposed tidal lagoon project would result in the death of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the company behind the project, disputed these figures, stating that their own modeling estimated a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality. NRW defended its assessment, claiming it was based on the "best available evidence" and expert analysis. They stated they had shared information, data, and methodology with TLP over an 18-month period.  The Welsh Government expressed support for the project while acknowledging the need for clarity from the UK government on its stance.

Northern Ireland's Department of Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities for both government and private sector organizations. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board to benefit the entire agri-food industry in Northern Ireland, which employs almost 100,000 people.  While Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomes the announcement, she recognizes that this new body will have implications for other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public to help plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon. The planting is part of a UK-wide project to plant millions of trees to commemorate the centenary of WWI.  The trees planted at Brackfield Wood will specifically honor the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in the conflict.  The Woodland Trust will provide the saplings and advises volunteers to wear welly boots or stout footwear.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award. The book was praised by judge and Radio Times TV editor Alison Graham, for being "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story". Ann Cleeves, Shetland and Vera writer and this year's festival programming chair, said the panel felt Hilary's book,  Someone Else's Skin, was "so finely written and tightly written". The book is a thriller that tackles domestic violence and so-called honour crime. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Cleeves praised Paretsky for creating a "strong female protagonist"  at a time when it was "pretty well unheard of" and for "chang[ing] the way that readers thought about female writers".
